Status Epilepticus.title: Status Epilepticus
Status Epilepticus.scope: ** Management of convulsive status epilepticus (CSE) and non-convulsive status epilepticus (NCSE) in adults. Covers staged treatment protocol from emergent benzodiazepines through refractory and super-refractory phases. Includes diagnostic workup to identify underlying etiology and specific protocols for NORSE/FIRES. Excludes pediatric status epilepticus, neonatal seizures, and psychogenic non-epileptic status.

Elevated in prolonged seizure; marker of severity

Extended Workup.rationale: Hepatic encephalopathy, valproate toxicity, urea cycle disorders

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Subacute onset, smoking history, weight loss

Essential/First-line.target: Mass, hemorrhage, stroke, herniation, hydrocephalus

Essential/First-line.timing: As soon as available; mandatory in RSE/SRSE
Essential/First-line.target: Seizure burden, treatment response, NCSE detection
Aspiration, ETT position

New Onset Seizure.title: New Onset Seizure
New Onset Seizure.scope: ** Initial evaluation and management of first-time unprovoked seizure or first presentation of seizure activity in adults. Covers immediate stabilization, diagnostic workup to identify etiology, acute treatment, and framework for anti-seizure medication (ASM) initiation. Excludes status epilepticus (see "Status Epilepticus" template), pediatric seizures, febrile seizures, and known epilepsy with breakthrough seizures.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Electrolyte abnormalities (Na, Ca, Mg, glucose), renal/hepatic function for ASM dosing
Illicit drugs (cocaine, amphetamines) and withdrawal states
Elevated if drawn within 10-20 min of event; helps distinguish seizure from non-epileptic event
Hypophosphatemia lowers seizure threshold (especially alcohol withdrawal)
Elevated post-ictal confirms recent seizure; metabolic acidosis screen

Extended Workup.rationale: Thyroid dysfunction can affect seizure threshold
Cardiac ischemia as cause or consequence
Eclampsia; affects imaging and ASM choice
Deficiency can lower threshold; important for women of childbearing potential

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Synthetic drugs, medications not on standard screen
Anti-NMDAR, LGI1, CASPR2, GABA-B if clinical suspicion

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: If clinical suspicion for autoimmune etiology

Essential/First-line.target: Mass, hemorrhage, stroke, calcification, hydrocephalus

If MRA unavailable and vascular cause suspected
If embolic stroke suspected as cause

Patient Instructions.item: **Return to ED immediately if:** recurrent seizure, prolonged seizure >5 minutes, head injury, persistent confusion, difficulty breathing, or status epilepticus
Do NOT drive until cleared by neurology (driving restrictions per state guidelines; typically require seizure-free interval)
Avoid operating heavy machinery, working at heights, or swimming alone
Do not bathe alone; showers preferred over baths; keep bathroom door unlocked
Inform employer if job involves safety-sensitive duties
Take ASM exactly as prescribed; do NOT stop abruptly (risk of breakthrough seizures or status epilepticus)
Avoid common seizure triggers: sleep deprivation, alcohol, illicit drugs, missed medications
Keep a seizure diary: date, time, duration, description, triggers, post-ictal symptoms
Wear medical identification (bracelet or necklace)
Educate family/coworkers on seizure first aid: stay with person, protect head, do NOT put anything in mouth, time the seizure, call 911 if >5 minutes
Follow up with neurology within 1-2 weeks of discharge
Bring list of all medications (including OTC and supplements) to all appointments - many interact with ASMs
Women: discuss contraception with provider; some ASMs reduce efficacy of hormonal contraception
Report side effects (mood changes, rash, dizziness, cognitive issues) promptly; do NOT stop medication without calling
Avoid flashing/strobe lights if photosensitive seizures suspected

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Sleep hygiene: aim for 7-9 hours nightly; maintain regular sleep schedule
Avoid alcohol (lowers seizure threshold; interacts with ASMs)
Avoid illicit drugs (especially stimulants: cocaine, amphetamines)
Stress management techniques
Regular moderate exercise (not extreme sleep deprivation from overtraining)
Medication adherence: use pill organizers, phone alarms, refill reminders
Folic acid supplementation 1-4 mg daily for women of childbearing potential (especially if on enzyme-inducing ASMs)
Bone health: vitamin D 1000-2000 IU daily; calcium as needed (enzyme-inducing ASMs affect bone density)
Avoid known personal triggers (flashing lights, certain foods, stress, if identified)
Home safety modifications: pad sharp furniture corners, avoid glass shower doors, use microwave instead of stovetop when alone
Seizure alert devices or apps for those living alone (optional)
Smoking cessation (increases ASM metabolism; general health)

differential.features: Brief (<15 sec), triggered by standing/Valsalva/micturition, rapid recovery, no post-ictal confusion, possible prodrome (lightheaded, tunnel vision)
differential.tests: ECG, orthostatic vitals, tilt table test, echocardiogram

Gradual onset, spreading symptoms, headache follows, stereotyped
Diaphoresis, tremor, confusion, rapid glucose corrects symptoms
Palpitations, sudden LOC without warning, rapid recovery
differential.tests: ECG, Holter monitor, event recorder, EP study

differential.features: Isolated anterograde amnesia, repetitive questioning, no convulsive activity
Occur from sleep, specific features (cataplexy with emotion)
Stereotyped, no LOC, suppressible (tics), may have sensory urge
History of substance use, known withdrawal timeline
Gradual onset, diffuse abnormality, asterixis, no discrete seizures

evidence.recommendation: MRI superior to CT for epilepsy evaluation
Levetiracetam non-inferior to phenytoin for acute seizure cessation
Risk of recurrence after first unprovoked seizure ~40-50%
Starting ASM after first seizure reduces recurrence but not long-term remission
Lamotrigine and levetiracetam preferred in women of childbearing potential
Prolactin elevation supports diagnosis of epileptic seizure (if drawn <20 min)
Continuous EEG detects non-convulsive status in altered patients

monitoring.item: Neurologic exam (level of consciousness, focal deficits)

monitoring.action: If prolonged post-ictal state: continuous EEG to rule out non-convulsive status
Supplemental O2; airway management; consider flumazenil only if severe

monitoring.action: Adjust dose; check free level for phenytoin

monitoring.action: Discontinue if hepatotoxicity; hold if transaminases >3× ULN

monitoring.action: Discontinue if significant bone marrow suppression
Reduce dose or switch if severe hyponatremia

monitoring.frequency: Within 24-48h of first seizure; repeat if diagnosis unclear
monitoring.action: Adjust treatment if epileptiform activity or non-convulsive seizures

monitoring.frequency: Within 2 weeks of first seizure; sooner if structural cause suspected
monitoring.action: Address structural cause; refer to appropriate specialist

disposition.criteria: Single, self-limited seizure; returned to baseline; no dangerous etiology identified on initial workup; reliable adult supervision for 24h; ASM initiated or deferred with close follow-up; outpatient EEG and MRI arranged; understands return precautions and driving restriction

Prolonged post-ictal period; multiple seizures; new structural lesion requiring monitoring; ASM loading requiring observation; social situation preventing safe discharge; need for inpatient EEG; new focal neurologic deficit

Status epilepticus (current or recent); recurrent seizures despite treatment; need for continuous EEG monitoring; airway compromise; hemodynamic instability; significant aspiration; large structural lesion with mass effect; CNS infection

Patient Instructions.item: Return to ED if rapid vision loss, sudden weakness, difficulty breathing, or urinary retention
Avoid driving until cleared by neurology
Heat may temporarily worsen symptoms (Uhthoff phenomenon) - this is not a new attack
Expect temporary steroid side effects: insomnia, mood changes, increased appetite, metallic taste
Keep symptom diary noting new or worsening symptoms
Do not stop steroids abruptly if on oral taper
Do not stop baclofen or tizanidine abruptly - risk of withdrawal/rebound spasticity
Monitor blood sugars if diabetic - steroids elevate glucose
Avoid sick contacts while on high-dose steroids
Contact MS specialist before starting any new medications (drug interactions with DMTs)
Vaccinations should be completed before DMT initiation (especially live vaccines)
Pregnancy planning requires DMT discussion (some DMTs teratogenic, washout periods vary)
Report any signs of infection (fever, cough, dysuria) promptly
Post-void residual check if difficulty emptying bladder or recurrent UTIs

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Smoking cessation (smoking accelerates MS progression and disability)
Vitamin D supplementation 2000-5000 IU daily (target serum 25-OH vitamin D >40 ng/mL)
Regular aerobic exercise 150 min/week as tolerated (improves fatigue, mood, function)
Resistance training 2-3Ã—/week
Stress management and adequate sleep (7-8 hours nightly)
Avoid excessive heat exposure (hot tubs, saunas, prolonged direct sun, exercising in heat)
Cooling vest for outdoor activities in warm weather
Maintain healthy weight (obesity associated with worse outcomes)
Limit alcohol intake (can worsen balance, cognition, bladder symptoms)
Ensure vaccinations up to date before DMT initiation (live vaccines contraindicated on many DMTs)
Fall prevention: remove loose rugs, ensure adequate lighting, use assistive devices if needed
Energy conservation techniques for fatigue management (pacing, prioritization, positioning)

differential.features: Longitudinally extensive transverse myelitis (â‰¥3 segments), severe optic neuritis (often bilateral), area postrema syndrome (intractable nausea/vomiting), brain lesions in NMOSD-typical locations
differential.tests: AQP4-IgG positive (Mayo CDS1 or NMOFS); MRI pattern different

differential.features: Bilateral optic neuritis, ADEM-like presentation, longitudinally extensive myelitis, cortical encephalitis, better steroid response, more favorable prognosis
Monophasic (usually), encephalopathy, post-infectious, large poorly-defined lesions, pediatric predominance
differential.tests: Clinical course, MRI pattern, MOG-IgG status

differential.features: Headache, encephalopathy, stroke-like episodes, multifocal infarcts
Cranial neuropathies (especially VII), hypothalamic involvement, leptomeningeal enhancement, hilar adenopathy
differential.tests: ACE level, chest CT, biopsy (non-caseating granulomas)

differential.features: Progressive course, deep gray matter/periventricular involvement, homogeneous enhancement, older/immunocompromised
Encephalopathy, hearing loss, branch retinal artery occlusions, corpus callosum "snowball" lesions
Progressive cognitive decline, tabes dorsalis, Argyll Robertson pupils, positive serology
Risk factors, vacuolar myelopathy, cognitive impairment
Subacute combined degeneration, dorsal column signs, peripheral neuropathy, macrocytic anemia
Headache history, non-specific white matter changes, no enhancement, no cord lesions
Older age, vascular risk factors, periventricular caps/halos, no enhancement, no cord lesions

monitoring.action: Insulin sliding scale; endocrine consult if persistent >250
Intermittent catheterization if >200 mL; urology referral
DMT escalation discussion if new activity
DMT escalation discussion if new activity
If positive/rising: PML risk stratification, consider DMT switch

disposition.criteria: Mild symptoms; able to ambulate safely; reliable follow-up within 1-2 weeks; no IV steroids needed OR completing outpatient infusion; stable baseline function; understands return precautions
Moderate-severe symptoms; needs IV steroids; functional decline requiring therapy; diagnostic uncertainty requiring expedited workup; unable to care for self at home
Severe myelitis with respiratory compromise (NIF >-30 declining toward -20); brainstem involvement with airway risk or autonomic instability; severe encephalopathy
PLEX needed but unavailable; MS specialist not available for complex decision-making; MRI unavailable for urgent imaging

Peripheral Neuropathy - New Diagnosis/Ev.title: Peripheral Neuropathy - New Diagnosis/Evaluation
icd10: G60.0 (Hereditary motor and sensory neuropathy - CMT)
Peripheral Neuropathy - New Diagnosis/Ev.scope: ** Initial diagnostic workup and symptomatic management of suspected or newly diagnosed peripheral neuropathy. Covers etiologic evaluation, electrodiagnostic testing, pain management, and lifestyle modifications. For acute inflammatory neuropathies (GBS, CIDP), use dedicated templates. For diabetic neuropathy-specific management, this template applies but see also diabetes care protocols for glycemic optimization.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Renal dysfunction (uremic neuropathy), hepatic disease, electrolytes

Extended Workup.rationale: Detects IGT missed by FBG/HbA1c; high yield in idiopathic neuropathy (34-62% have abnormal OGTT)
Deficiency OR toxicity (>200 mg/day) causes neuropathy

Rare/Specialized.rationale: If motor-predominant or acute onset (GBS variants)
Subacute sensory neuronopathy, weight loss, smoking

Rare/Specialized.item: Fat pad or sural nerve biopsy
Heavy metal panel (lead, arsenic, thallium, mercury)

Patient Instructions.item: Return to ED if sudden severe weakness, difficulty breathing, or rapid symptom progression
Inspect feet daily for cuts, blisters, or wounds (use mirror for soles)
Wear well-fitting, protective footwear at all times (never barefoot)
Test bath water temperature with elbow or thermometer before entering (avoid burns)
Avoid prolonged hot or cold exposure to affected extremities (impaired sensation increases injury risk)
Use night lights and handrails to prevent falls
Report new numbness, weakness, or autonomic symptoms (dizziness, bladder changes)
Keep pain medication diary to track effectiveness and side effects
Do not stop gabapentin/pregabalin abruptly - taper under medical guidance
Neuropathic pain medications take 2-4 weeks to reach full effect
Avoid alcohol (worsens neuropathy, interacts with pain medications)
Rise slowly from sitting/lying position if orthostatic hypotension present
Increase salt and fluid intake if orthostatic (unless contraindicated by cardiac/renal disease)
Wear compression stockings for orthostatic hypotension
Do not drive until cleared if significant sensory loss or weakness affects pedal control
B12 injections: if self-administering, use proper technique and rotate injection sites

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Strict glycemic control (HbA1c <7% or individualized target) - most important modifiable factor
Complete alcohol cessation (alcoholic neuropathy is reversible if early)
Smoking cessation (microvascular disease worsens neuropathy)
Regular exercise as tolerated (improves circulation, glycemic control, reduces pain)
Balance exercises and strength training (PT-guided) to prevent falls
Pool therapy/aquatic exercise (reduces fall risk while exercising)
Vitamin B12 supplementation if vegan/vegetarian or on metformin
Review medications for neurotoxic agents (metronidazole, nitrofurantoin, chemotherapy, amiodarone, statins)
Avoid excessive vitamin B6 supplementation (>100 mg/day can cause neuropathy)
Blood pressure control (target <130/80 for diabetic patients)
Weight loss if obese (reduces pressure on nerves, improves metabolic syndrome)
Fall prevention: remove throw rugs, ensure adequate lighting, use assistive devices
Annual foot exams by podiatry or primary care for diabetic patients
Regular ophthalmology exams if diabetic (concurrent retinopathy common)

differential.features: Acute ascending weakness <4 weeks, areflexia, post-infectious
differential.tests: NCS early may be normal then demyelinating; CSF albuminocytologic dissociation

differential.tests: Genetic testing; NCS shows uniform slowing in CMT1

HbA1c <7% reduces neuropathy incidence in Type 1 DM
Gabapentin, pregabalin, duloxetine first-line for painful diabetic neuropathy
Tricyclic antidepressants effective for neuropathic pain
NCS/EMG for characterization of peripheral neuropathy
SPEP indicated in idiopathic neuropathy workup
OGTT detects IGT in 34-62% of idiopathic neuropathy patients

disposition.criteria: Stable symptoms; chronic/slowly progressive course; ambulatory; reliable follow-up with neurology within 2-4 weeks; pain controlled; able to perform ADLs; no fall risk requiring inpatient therapy

Acute/subacute progression concerning for GBS or CIDP; significant functional decline; falls requiring therapy evaluation; severe uncontrolled pain; new autonomic instability; workup requiring inpatient procedures (nerve biopsy, LP)
GBS with respiratory compromise (FVC <20 mL/kg, NIF >-30, or declining trajectory); autonomic instability with cardiac arrhythmia or BP lability; aspiration risk
EMG/NCS not available urgently; neuromuscular specialist not available; PLEX/IVIG needed but not available; rehabilitation services not available

Acute Ischemic Stroke.scope: ** Emergency evaluation and treatment of acute ischemic stroke, including thrombolysis decision-making, mechanical thrombectomy candidacy, acute stroke unit care, secondary prevention, and etiologic workup. For hemorrhagic stroke, TIA, or venous sinus thrombosis, use dedicated templates.

Patient Instructions.item: Call 911 immediately if new or worsening weakness, numbness, vision changes, speech difficulty, or severe headache
Know stroke warning signs: F.A.S.T. (Face drooping, Arm weakness, Speech difficulty, Time to call 911)
Take all prescribed medications as directed; do not stop antiplatelet or anticoagulant without physician guidance
Attend all follow-up appointments (neurology, cardiology, primary care)
No driving until cleared by physician (typically minimum 2-4 weeks; varies by state law and deficit severity)
Report any bleeding (blood in stool, urine, gums, excessive bruising) while on blood thinners
Check blood pressure at home daily if hypertensive; keep log for follow-up visits
Monitor blood glucose if diabetic; maintain good glycemic control
Follow swallow precautions if dysphagia present (diet modification, positioning, supervision)
Use fall precautions: clear pathways, use assistive devices as prescribed, adequate lighting

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Smoking cessation (most important modifiable risk factor)
Blood pressure control: target <130/80 mmHg
LDL cholesterol target <70 mg/dL (or 50% reduction) with high-intensity statin
Diabetes management: HbA1c target <7%

Use energy conservation techniques including scheduled rest periods to manage post-GBS fatigue

Report any new neurological symptoms weeks after discharge as post-HSV autoimmune encephalitis can occur 2-6 weeks later
Attend neurology follow-up in 2-4 weeks to assess recovery and screen for delayed complications
Expect that cognitive rehabilitation may be needed as memory and behavioral deficits are common after HSVE
Contact Encephalitis Society (www.encephalitis.info) for patient support and educational resources

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Use fall precautions including walker and supervision due to weakness and cognitive impairment
Aspiration precautions including thickened liquids and upright positioning if bulbar involvement present
Maintain adequate hydration (2-3 L/day) to prevent acyclovir-induced nephrotoxicity
Follow seizure safety including no swimming alone and showers instead of baths due to ongoing seizure risk
Use cognitive pacing with scheduled rest periods to manage post-encephalitis fatigue
Do not drive until cleared by neurology due to seizure risk and potential cognitive impairment

Autoimmune Encephalitis.title: Autoimmune Encephalitis
icd10: G13.1 (Other systemic atrophy primarily affecting CNS in neoplastic disease)
Autoimmune Encephalitis.scope: ** Evaluation and management of autoimmune encephalitis in adults, including antibody-mediated (anti-NMDAR, LGI1, CASPR2, GABA-B, AMPA, etc.) and paraneoplastic encephalitis. Covers diagnostic workup, tumor screening, first-line and second-line immunotherapy, and long-term management. Excludes infectious encephalitis, Hashimoto's encephalopathy (SREAT), and pediatric-specific presentations.

Patient Instructions.item: Return immediately if worsening confusion, seizures, or new symptoms develop (may indicate relapse requiring treatment escalation)
Continue immunotherapy as prescribed even when feeling better; stopping early increases relapse risk
Report fever or signs of infection promptly as immunosuppression increases infection risk
Follow seizure precautions including no driving, swimming alone, or heights due to unpredictable seizure risk
Attend all follow-up appointments as relapses can occur months to years after initial presentation
Expect that recovery may take months to years; improvement often continues for 2+ years
Participate in cognitive rehabilitation as this is essential for optimizing recovery from memory and executive deficits
Contact Autoimmune Encephalitis Alliance (www.aealliance.org) for patient support and educational resources

Avoid live vaccines while on immunosuppression; inactivated vaccines are safe and recommended
Practice infection prevention including hand hygiene and avoiding sick contacts while on immunosuppression
Continue regular cancer screening for paraneoplastic cases as tumor recurrence can trigger relapse
Use cognitive pacing with scheduled rest periods to manage post-encephalitis fatigue
Do not drive until cleared by neurology due to seizure risk and cognitive impairment

Patient Instructions.item: Return immediately for sudden severe headache different from typical migraine ("worst headache of life") which may indicate hemorrhage
Return immediately for headache with fever, stiff neck, or altered mental status which may indicate infection

Identify and avoid personal triggers (stress, sleep changes, skipped meals, alcohol, specific foods)

Regular meals to avoid fasting-triggered migraine; do not skip breakfast
Aerobic exercise (30 min moderate activity 5x/week) shown to reduce migraine frequency
Stress management through relaxation techniques, mindfulness, or biofeedback
Caffeine moderation (≤200 mg/day equivalent to 2 cups coffee) and consistent daily intake
Adequate hydration (at least 64 oz water daily) as dehydration can trigger migraine
Limit alcohol especially red wine which is a common trigger

Patient Instructions.item: Call 911 immediately if symptoms return as this indicates high stroke risk (up to 10% in first 48 hours)
Do not drive for at least 2-4 weeks after TIA per state regulations and stroke risk
Take all medications as prescribed especially antiplatelet therapy which significantly reduces stroke risk

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Blood pressure target <130/80 mmHg to significantly reduce stroke recurrence risk
LDL target <70 mg/dL with high-intensity statin for secondary prevention

Limit alcohol to ≤1 drink/day for women, ≤2 drinks/day for men
Regular aerobic exercise (150 min/week moderate or 75 min/week vigorous)
Weight management with target BMI 18.5-24.9 kg/m²
Sodium restriction <2300 mg/day (ideally <1500 mg if hypertensive)

Patient Instructions.item: Return immediately if sudden confusion worsens which may indicate stroke, infection, or medication effect
Complete advance directives while patient has capacity to document wishes for future care
Establish healthcare proxy/power of attorney for future decision-making
Do not drive if cognitive impairment affects judgment or reaction time (formal driving evaluation may be needed)
Take all medications as prescribed and use pill organizers or reminders to ensure adherence
Keep a consistent daily routine which helps with orientation and reduces confusion
Engage in mentally stimulating activities (reading, puzzles, social interaction) to support cognitive reserve

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Regular physical exercise (150 min/week moderate aerobic) may slow cognitive decline
Mediterranean or MIND diet emphasizing vegetables, berries, fish, nuts, and olive oil
Adequate sleep (7-8 hours) and treat sleep disorders (sleep apnea assessment)
Social engagement and cognitive stimulation through activities, hobbies, and relationships
Cardiovascular risk factor control (BP <130/80, diabetes control, cholesterol management) reduces vascular contribution
Hearing loss correction with hearing aids as untreated hearing loss is modifiable dementia risk factor
Limit alcohol to ≤1 drink daily as excess alcohol accelerates cognitive decline
Fall prevention with home modifications as dementia increases fall and injury risk

Patient Instructions.item: CRITICAL: Do not skip or delay levodopa doses as this can cause severe OFF episodes and immobility
Take levodopa 30-60 minutes before meals for better absorption (protein competes with levodopa transport)
Rise slowly from sitting or lying to prevent falls from orthostatic hypotension
Inform all healthcare providers about PD medications to avoid drug interactions (especially antipsychotics, antiemetics)
Report any new impulsive behaviors (gambling, shopping, hypersexuality) which may indicate impulse control disorder from dopamine agonists
Report hallucinations early as these can be managed with medication adjustment
Engage in regular exercise which may slow disease progression and improves mobility

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Regular aerobic exercise (30-60 min, 3-5x/week) improves motor function and may be neuroprotective
Tai chi or dance-based exercise programs improve balance and reduce falls
High-fiber diet and adequate hydration to prevent constipation
Avoid medications that worsen parkinsonism (metoclopramide, prochlorperazine, haloperidol, risperidone)
Fall prevention: remove home hazards, adequate lighting, grab bars, non-slip surfaces
Mediterranean diet may have protective benefits based on observational studies
Coffee consumption associated with reduced PD risk; continued moderate use reasonable

Referrals & Consults.item: Headache specialist/Neurology referral for diagnosis confirmation and preventive therapy optimization
Pain management referral for interventional procedures (nerve blocks, neuromodulation evaluation) in refractory cases
Sleep medicine evaluation for polysomnography if obstructive sleep apnea suspected as cluster trigger
Endocrinology referral if pituitary abnormality identified on imaging or atypical hormone levels
Neurosurgery consultation for neuromodulation or ablative procedures in medically refractory cases
Cardiology clearance before initiating high-dose verapamil in patients with cardiac history
Psychiatry referral for suicidal ideation screening given high depression/suicide risk in cluster headache patients

Patient Instructions.item: Return immediately for sudden severe headache different from typical cluster attacks which may indicate new pathology
Keep high-flow oxygen available at home during cluster period for acute attack treatment
Use sumatriptan injection at first sign of attack for fastest relief; do not wait for pain to worsen
Maintain detailed headache diary including attack timing, duration, severity, and treatment response
Avoid known triggers during cluster period especially alcohol (even small amounts), strong odors, and napping
Do not abruptly stop preventive medications especially lithium and baclofen which require gradual taper
Carry injectable sumatriptan at all times during active cluster period for emergency use
Alert healthcare providers to cluster headache diagnosis as this affects anesthesia and medication choices

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Strict alcohol avoidance during entire cluster period as even small amounts trigger attacks
Maintain regular sleep schedule with consistent bedtime and wake time to regulate circadian rhythm
Avoid daytime napping during cluster period as sleep transitions can trigger attacks
Smoking cessation to reduce vascular risk and potential cluster exacerbation
Avoid high altitude exposure during cluster period if altitude is a known trigger
Avoid vasodilators (nitroglycerin, sildenafil) during cluster period as these trigger attacks
Screen for and treat obstructive sleep apnea as treatment may reduce cluster frequency
Stress management techniques as emotional stress may influence cluster cycle onset
Avoid strong chemical odors (solvents, perfumes, gasoline) which can trigger attacks in some patients

Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI).title: Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI)
Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI).scope: ** Outpatient-focused evaluation for MCI, identification of reversible causes, subtype classification (amnestic vs non-amnestic), risk factor modification, monitoring for progression, and symptomatic treatment. Includes guidance on disease-modifying therapy eligibility (anti-amyloid agents) and advance care planning.

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology/Cognitive neurology for MCI subtype characterization, biomarker interpretation, and treatment planning
Neuropsychology for comprehensive cognitive testing to establish baseline, characterize affected domains, and distinguish MCI subtypes
Geriatrics for comprehensive geriatric assessment, polypharmacy review, and functional optimization
Occupational therapy for cognitive strategies, compensatory techniques, and home safety evaluation
Occupational therapy driving evaluation to assess fitness to drive given cognitive impairment
Social work for community resources, support services, and early care planning guidance
Speech therapy for communication strategies if language domain affected (non-amnestic MCI)
Sleep medicine for sleep apnea evaluation if symptoms present (snoring, daytime sleepiness, witnessed apneas)
Psychiatry for depression evaluation if significant mood symptoms confounding cognitive assessment
Genetics counseling if early-onset (<65), family history of early-onset dementia, or considering genetic testing
Clinical trial referral for eligible patients interested in research studies targeting MCI and early AD
Elder law attorney for advance directives, healthcare proxy, and financial planning while patient has full capacity
PCP follow-up for cardiovascular risk factor management and coordination of vascular prevention

Patient Instructions.item: Return if sudden confusion worsens or new neurological symptoms develop which may indicate stroke or other acute process
Complete advance directives and establish healthcare proxy NOW while you have full capacity to make decisions
Consider long-term care preferences, financial planning, and legal arrangements with family while fully competent
Discuss driving safety with physician; formal driving evaluation recommended as MCI may affect reaction time and judgment
Use memory aids (calendars, smartphone reminders, pill organizers, written lists) to compensate for memory difficulties
Keep a consistent daily routine which helps with memory and reduces confusion
Take all medications as prescribed; bring medication list to all appointments
Return for follow-up cognitive testing every 6-12 months to monitor for progression
Report new memory concerns, personality changes, or functional difficulties to physician promptly
Avoid anticholinergic medications (diphenhydramine, PM sleep aids) as they can worsen cognition

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Engage in regular aerobic exercise (150 minutes/week moderate intensity) which may slow cognitive decline and improve brain health
Follow Mediterranean or MIND diet emphasizing vegetables, berries, fish, nuts, whole grains, and olive oil to reduce dementia risk
Participate in cognitively stimulating activities (reading, puzzles, learning new skills, social engagement) to build cognitive reserve
Maintain active social connections and relationships as social isolation is a modifiable dementia risk factor
Achieve adequate sleep (7-8 hours nightly) and treat sleep disorders (CPAP for sleep apnea) as poor sleep accelerates cognitive decline
Cardiovascular risk factor control with target BP <130/80, HbA1c <7%, LDL <100 to reduce vascular contribution to cognitive decline
Address hearing loss with hearing aids as untreated hearing loss is a modifiable risk factor for cognitive decline
Limit alcohol to maximum 1 drink daily as excess alcohol accelerates brain atrophy and cognitive decline
Smoking cessation to reduce vascular risk and improve overall brain health
Manage stress through relaxation techniques, mindfulness, or counseling as chronic stress impairs cognition
Review all medications with physician to identify and discontinue drugs that impair cognition (anticholinergics, benzodiazepines, opioids)

Chronic Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyn.title: Chronic Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy (CIDP)
Chronic Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyn.scope: ** Evaluation, diagnosis, treatment initiation, and long-term management of CIDP in adults. Covers typical CIDP, CIDP variants (MADSAM, DADS, sensory CIDP), first-line immunotherapy (IVIg, corticosteroids, plasmapheresis), second-line immunosuppressants, and subcutaneous immunoglobulin therapy. Primary focus is outpatient management with coverage for acute presentations and hospitalizations. Excludes Guillain-Barré syndrome (acute onset <8 weeks), hereditary neuropathies (CMT), and pediatric CIDP.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Inflammatory marker; elevated in some CIDP
Diabetic neuropathy in differential; diabetes worsens CIDP
Confirms monoclonal protein if SPEP abnormal
Prior HBV exposure; reactivation risk with immunosuppression

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology consult for diagnosis confirmation, treatment initiation, and long-term management planning
Neuromuscular specialist referral for diagnostic uncertainty, treatment-refractory cases, or consideration of advanced therapies
Infusion center referral for ongoing IVIg administration and monitoring
Home infusion service referral for SCIg training and home therapy setup
Physical therapy for gait training, fall prevention, strengthening exercises, and mobility optimization
Occupational therapy for ADL assessment, adaptive equipment, and energy conservation strategies
Pain management consult for refractory neuropathic pain not responding to gabapentin/pregabalin/duloxetine
Endocrinology consult for steroid-induced diabetes management or osteoporosis prevention
Hematology consult if monoclonal protein detected for POEMS or myeloma workup
Pulmonology consult if respiratory symptoms develop (rare in CIDP; consider GBS overlap)
Rheumatology consult if connective tissue disease suspected based on labs or clinical features
Social work for disability resources, transportation assistance, and community support services
PCP follow-up for chronic disease management, steroid side effect monitoring, and preventive care

Patient Instructions.item: Return immediately if progressive weakness, difficulty walking, or breathing problems develop (may indicate disease progression or acute worsening)
Keep all IVIg/infusion appointments as scheduled to maintain disease control and prevent relapses
Do not stop immunosuppressive medications suddenly as this may cause disease flare; taper only under physician guidance
Report signs of infection (fever, cough, dysuria) promptly as immunosuppression increases infection risk
Use fall precautions including handrails, non-slip surfaces, and assistive devices due to balance and weakness
Perform home exercises as prescribed by physical therapy to maintain strength and flexibility
Monitor for IVIg side effects including headache, fever, chills, or rash during infusions; report severe symptoms
Keep a symptom diary tracking strength, numbness, and functional abilities to share at follow-up visits
Carry a medical ID card indicating CIDP diagnosis and current treatments in case of emergency
Contact GBS-CIDP Foundation (www.gbs-cidp.org) for patient education, support groups, and resources

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Maintain glycemic control (HbA1c <7%) to prevent worsening of neuropathy if diabetic
Limit alcohol consumption as alcohol worsens peripheral neuropathy and interacts with medications
Ensure adequate vitamin B12 and folate intake through diet or supplementation to support nerve health
Avoid smoking as it impairs circulation and may worsen neuropathy
Stay up to date on vaccinations (flu, pneumonia, COVID-19, shingles) but avoid live vaccines while on immunosuppression
Wear protective footwear to prevent injury to numb feet and avoid burns or trauma
Perform daily foot inspections for wounds or ulcers given sensory loss
Engage in low-impact exercise (swimming, stationary cycling, walking) to maintain cardiovascular health and strength
Maintain bone health with calcium, vitamin D, and weight-bearing exercise, especially if on steroids
Manage stress and get adequate sleep as fatigue worsens CIDP symptoms

Referrals & Consults.item: Headache specialist/Neurology referral for refractory MOH management and preventive optimization
Pain psychology/Behavioral medicine referral for cognitive behavioral therapy addressing medication-seeking behaviors and pain catastrophizing
Addiction medicine consultation for opioid-overuse MOH with features of opioid use disorder
Primary care physician coordination for chronic disease management and medication reconciliation
Psychiatry referral for comorbid depression, anxiety, or substance use disorder requiring pharmacotherapy
Physical therapy for cervicogenic headache component and postural evaluation
Social work consultation for disability resources, work accommodations, or financial assistance for medications

Patient Instructions.item: Expect temporary worsening of headaches during the first 1-2 weeks of withdrawal (rebound headache period); this is normal and necessary for improvement
Most patients experience significant improvement within 2-3 months after successful withdrawal
Return immediately for severe headache with fever, stiff neck, or altered mental status which may indicate infection requiring emergency evaluation
Return immediately for sudden severe headache different from usual ("worst headache of life") which may indicate hemorrhage
Return if experiencing severe withdrawal symptoms including seizure, tremor, or hallucinations (especially with barbiturate or opioid overuse)
Limit acute headache medication use to maximum 2 days per week to prevent recurrent MOH
Maintain detailed headache diary tracking headache days, medication use days, and triggers
Do not abruptly stop butalbital-containing medications (Fioricet, Fiorinal) as this may cause seizures; must taper under physician guidance
Preventive medications may take 4-8 weeks to show full benefit; continue as prescribed even if headaches persist initially

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Regular sleep schedule (7-8 hours, consistent bedtime/wake time) as irregular sleep triggers headache
Regular meals to avoid fasting-triggered headache; do not skip meals
Aerobic exercise (30 min moderate activity 5x/week) shown to reduce headache frequency and improve mood
Stress management through relaxation techniques, mindfulness, or biofeedback to reduce headache triggers
Adequate hydration (at least 64 oz water daily) as dehydration can trigger headache
Caffeine consistency: if using caffeine, maintain consistent daily intake; if tapering, reduce gradually over 2 weeks
Alcohol avoidance during withdrawal period as it can worsen headaches and interact with medications
Avoid keeping overused medications at home during withdrawal to reduce temptation and relapse risk

Multiple Sclerosis - Chronic Management.title: Multiple Sclerosis - Chronic Management
Multiple Sclerosis - Chronic Management.scope: ** Long-term management of established MS including disease-modifying therapy (DMT) monitoring, symptom management optimization, surveillance imaging, preventive care, and special populations (pregnancy planning). Excludes acute MS relapse (see "MS - Exacerbation") and initial diagnostic workup (see "MS - New Diagnosis"). Primary focus is outpatient management with guidance for ED/hospital presentation of established MS patients.

Referrals & Consults.item: MS specialist/Neuroimmunology for annual comprehensive review and DMT optimization
Neuro-ophthalmology for visual complaints, OCT monitoring, or suspected optic neuritis
Physical therapy for gait training, balance exercises, and fall prevention given progressive mobility decline
Occupational therapy for ADL assessment, energy conservation strategies, and adaptive equipment
Speech therapy for dysphagia evaluation given brainstem involvement or swallowing concerns
Neuropsychology for formal cognitive testing if subjective or objective cognitive decline
Cognitive rehabilitation (speech therapy or neuropsychology) for documented cognitive impairment
Urology for refractory bladder symptoms, recurrent UTIs, or urodynamic testing consideration
Psychiatry for depression, anxiety, or adjustment disorders not responding to first-line treatment
Pain management for refractory neuropathic pain not responding to multiple first-line agents
Physiatry/Rehabilitation medicine for comprehensive rehabilitation planning and spasticity management
Social work for disability planning, insurance navigation, and community resource connection
Genetic counseling if considering pregnancy with strong family history or known genetic mutations
High-risk OB for pregnancy planning discussion in women on DMTs
Infusion center for DMT administration and monitoring
Palliative care for advanced MS with significant symptom burden or goals of care discussions

Patient Instructions.item: Return immediately if rapid vision loss, new weakness, numbness, or difficulty walking develops (may indicate relapse requiring steroids)
Report fever or signs of infection promptly as immunomodulatory DMTs increase infection risk
Continue DMT as prescribed unless instructed otherwise by neurology - do not stop without discussing
Avoid live vaccines while on immunosuppressive DMTs (fingolimod, siponimod, cladribine, anti-CD20 therapies, alemtuzumab)
Heat may temporarily worsen symptoms (Uhthoff phenomenon) - use cooling strategies; this is NOT a new relapse
Maintain symptom diary noting new symptoms, fatigue levels, and bladder/bowel patterns
Do not stop baclofen or tizanidine abruptly - taper under medical supervision to avoid withdrawal
Report any skin changes, new moles, or suspicious lesions given increased malignancy risk with some DMTs
Women of childbearing potential: discuss pregnancy plans with MS specialist before conception given DMT-specific washout requirements
Report unusual fatigue, shortness of breath, chest pain, or palpitations if on S1P modulators (cardiac effects)
If on natalizumab: report any new neurological symptoms, especially if subtle (confusion, personality change, clumsiness) as may indicate PML
Take dalfampridine exactly 12 hours apart and never exceed 2 doses per day (seizure risk)

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Smoking cessation - smoking accelerates MS progression, increases relapse rate, and worsens disability
Vitamin D supplementation 2000-5000 IU daily to maintain serum 25-OH vitamin D >40 ng/mL (target >50 ng/mL)
Regular aerobic exercise 150 minutes per week as tolerated - improves fatigue, mood, mobility, and may slow progression
Aquatic therapy/swimming - allows exercise with built-in cooling and reduced fall risk
Resistance training 2-3 times weekly for strength maintenance and bone health
Stress management techniques as stress may trigger pseudorelapses and worsen fatigue
Sleep hygiene - ensure 7-8 hours nightly; address sleep disorders contributing to fatigue
Avoid excessive heat exposure (hot tubs, saunas, exercising in heat) - use cooling vests for outdoor activities
Fall prevention: remove loose rugs, ensure adequate lighting, use assistive devices (cane, walker) as needed
Complete recommended vaccinations before starting immunosuppressive DMTs - inactivated vaccines safe on most DMTs
Annual influenza vaccine (inactivated) and COVID-19 vaccines per current guidelines (timing around infusions for anti-CD20)
Limit alcohol intake as it can worsen balance, cognitive symptoms, and interact with medications
Mediterranean diet pattern may have anti-inflammatory benefits based on observational data
DEXA scan for bone density monitoring if prolonged steroid exposure, immobility, or menopause

Progressive; dorsal column signs; may coexist with MS
Progressive; atypical pattern; on immunosuppressive DMT

Every 3-6 months for stable patients; q1-3 months during DMT transition or active disease; annually minimum for established stable patients

Restless Legs Syndrome.title: Restless Legs Syndrome
Restless Legs Syndrome.scope: ** Diagnosis confirmation using IRLSSG criteria, workup for secondary causes, pharmacologic and non-pharmacologic management, and augmentation prevention/treatment. Primarily outpatient management with limited ED/HOSP coverage for severe refractory cases.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Iron deficiency is most common treatable cause; target >75 ng/mL for RLS (higher than general population)
Iron availability; TSAT <20% suggests iron deficiency even with normal ferritin
Iron binding capacity; elevated in iron deficiency
Anemia evaluation; MCV for iron vs B12 deficiency
Thyroid dysfunction can mimic or exacerbate RLS

Extended Workup.rationale: Deficiency causes neuropathy and may worsen RLS
Deficiency associated with RLS; often low with B12
Deficiency can cause leg cramps and muscle symptoms
Inflammatory markers; chronic inflammation affects iron metabolism
RLS common in pregnancy (up to 25%); affects treatment choices

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Nephrotic syndrome workup if renal disease suspected
Deficiency associated with RLS in some studies

Essential/First-line.target: IRLSSG criteria met; no mimicking conditions
Score 0-40; mild <10, moderate 11-20, severe 21-30, very severe >30

If peripheral neuropathy suspected (numbness, weakness, areflexia)
Objective assessment of sleep and limb movements

Radiculopathy suspected; nerve root compression symptoms

Patient Instructions.item: Take iron supplements on an empty stomach every other day (better absorption) with vitamin C; avoid taking with calcium, coffee, or tea
Take evening medications 2-3 hours before typical symptom onset for best effect
Report symptoms spreading to arms, occurring earlier in day, or becoming more intense (signs of augmentation)
Report new gambling urges, compulsive shopping, or hypersexuality if taking dopamine agonists (impulse control disorders)
Avoid antihistamines (diphenhydramine, Benadryl) which significantly worsen RLS - use alternatives for allergies or sleep
Inform prescribers about RLS before starting new medications as many can worsen symptoms
Keep a symptom diary tracking severity, timing, and potential triggers to optimize treatment
Return if symptoms become severe enough to affect sleep, daytime function, or quality of life

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Avoid caffeine especially in afternoon and evening as it worsens RLS symptoms
Limit or avoid alcohol which disrupts sleep architecture and can worsen RLS
Avoid nicotine/smoking which can exacerbate symptoms through vasoconstriction and sleep disruption
Regular moderate exercise (walking, swimming, yoga) earlier in day reduces symptoms; avoid vigorous exercise near bedtime
Maintain regular sleep schedule with consistent bed and wake times (sleep hygiene)
Leg massage, warm baths, or heating pads in the evening may provide temporary symptomatic relief
Cooling measures (cold compresses, leg wraps) may help some patients
Mental distraction activities (engaging video games, puzzles) can reduce symptom awareness
Compression stockings or pneumatic compression may provide relief in some patients
Review all current medications with provider to identify and eliminate RLS-exacerbating drugs

Tension-Type Headache.title: Tension-Type Headache

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology/Headache specialist referral for chronic TTH (≥15 days/month) not responding to first-line preventives
Physical therapy for cervicogenic component, postural dysfunction, and pericranial muscle tension
Behavioral medicine/Psychology for stress management, biofeedback, and cognitive behavioral therapy
Sleep medicine evaluation if underlying sleep disorder (insomnia, apnea) contributing to chronic headache
Ophthalmology evaluation to rule out refractive error or eye strain as contributing factor
Dentistry/TMJ specialist if temporomandibular joint dysfunction contributing to headache
Psychiatry referral for comorbid depression or anxiety requiring pharmacologic management beyond preventive therapy

Patient Instructions.item: Return immediately for sudden severe headache ("worst headache of life") which may indicate hemorrhage or other serious cause
Return immediately for headache with fever, stiff neck, or altered mental status which may indicate infection
Return if new neurological symptoms develop (weakness, numbness, vision changes, speech difficulty)
Maintain headache diary tracking frequency, triggers, medication use, and response to guide treatment optimization
Limit acute pain medication use to no more than 10 days per month to prevent medication overuse headache
Take acute medications early at headache onset for best efficacy rather than waiting for severe pain
Identify and modify personal triggers (stress, poor posture, inadequate sleep, screen time, skipped meals)

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Regular sleep schedule (7-8 hours, consistent bedtime and wake time) as sleep disturbance is a common trigger
Stress management through relaxation techniques, mindfulness meditation, or progressive muscle relaxation
Regular aerobic exercise (30 minutes moderate activity 5 times/week) shown to reduce chronic headache frequency
Ergonomic workplace assessment to optimize posture and reduce neck/shoulder strain during computer work
Limit screen time and take regular breaks (20-20-20 rule: every 20 minutes, look 20 feet away for 20 seconds)
Adequate hydration (at least 64 oz water daily) as dehydration can trigger headache
Regular meals to avoid fasting-triggered headache; do not skip meals
Limit caffeine to moderate consistent intake (≤200 mg/day or ~2 cups coffee) to prevent withdrawal headaches
Stretching exercises for neck and shoulders daily, especially if sedentary work

Migraine with Aura.title: Migraine with Aura
Migraine with Aura.scope: ** Diagnosis and management of migraine with typical aura (visual, sensory, language) and hemiplegic migraine. Focuses on outpatient management with acute care considerations. Covers differentiation from TIA/stroke, contraceptive counseling, and preventive therapy. Excludes migraine with brainstem aura (separate protocol) and retinal migraine.

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology/Headache specialist referral for aura characterization, preventive optimization, and differentiation from other neurological conditions
OB/GYN consultation for contraceptive counseling - **estrogen-containing contraceptives contraindicated** in migraine with aura due to elevated ischemic stroke risk
Cardiology referral if TTE shows PFO for discussion of closure in select cases (recurrent cryptogenic stroke or debilitating aura despite medical therapy)
Genetics consultation if hemiplegic migraine suspected for CACNA1A, ATP1A2, SCN1A testing and family counseling
Physical therapy for cervicogenic component and trigger point management
Psychology/Behavioral medicine for CBT addressing aura anxiety, attack anticipation, and comorbid mood disorders
Ophthalmology if visual aura atypical or concern for retinal pathology
Sleep medicine if sleep disorder contributing to migraine frequency (OSA, insomnia)

Patient Instructions.item: Return immediately for new/different headache, "worst headache of life," or thunderclap onset which may indicate subarachnoid hemorrhage
Return immediately if aura persists >60 minutes or if new weakness on one side of body develops (need to rule out stroke)
Return immediately for headache with fever, stiff neck, or altered mental status which may indicate CNS infection
**AVOID estrogen-containing contraceptives** (combined birth control pills, patch, ring) - use progestin-only methods (mini-pill, Depo-Provera, Mirena IUD, Nexplanon) or non-hormonal methods
Triptans ARE safe for your typical visual/sensory aura - take at headache onset or when aura ends; do NOT take if you experience weakness (motor aura)
Maintain headache/aura diary tracking aura type, duration, triggers, and medication use to guide treatment optimization
Limit acute medication use to ≤10 days/month to prevent medication overuse headache which worsens both headache and aura
Learn your personal aura warning signs and take acute medication promptly when headache begins
Do not drive or operate machinery during visual or motor aura as vision and coordination may be impaired

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Regular sleep schedule (7-8 hours, consistent bedtime) as sleep changes are a major aura trigger
Avoid known aura triggers (bright/flashing lights, high altitude, significant sleep deprivation, extreme stress)
Regular aerobic exercise (30 min moderate activity 5x/week) reduces migraine frequency; avoid if currently in aura
Magnesium-rich diet (leafy greens, nuts, whole grains) or supplementation as magnesium specifically helps aura
Stress management techniques (mindfulness, biofeedback, relaxation training) as stress is a major trigger
Adequate hydration (at least 64 oz water daily) as dehydration can trigger attacks
Smoking cessation to reduce vascular risk, particularly important given aura-associated stroke risk
Caffeine moderation (≤200 mg/day) and consistent daily intake to avoid withdrawal triggers
Blood pressure control (target <130/80) given elevated vascular risk with aura
Avoid high altitude or rapid altitude changes if altitude is a known aura trigger

differential.features: Sudden onset (maximal at onset vs gradual aura spread); negative symptoms (vision loss vs positive scintillations); vascular risk factors; older age; duration usually <1 hr
differential.tests: MRI DWI (no restriction in aura); MRA/CTA (no vessel occlusion); aura has visual "march"

differential.features: Fixed deficit; sudden onset; vascular territory distribution; risk factors
differential.tests: MRI DWI (shows restriction); CT may be normal early

differential.tests: Clinical criteria; MRI to exclude posterior fossa lesion

differential.features: Monocular visual symptoms (vs binocular in typical aura); complete vision loss in one eye
differential.tests: Ophthalmology exam; cover/uncover test during symptoms

differential.features: Shorter duration (seconds to minutes); positive phenomena; may have automatisms; post-ictal confusion
differential.tests: EEG may show epileptiform activity; MRI for structural lesion

differential.features: Anterograde amnesia; repetitive questioning; no visual or motor symptoms; resolves <24 hr
differential.tests: Clinical diagnosis; MRI may show hippocampal DWI changes

differential.features: Age >50; scalp tenderness; jaw claudication; visual loss (not scintillations); elevated ESR/CRP
Neck pain; Horner syndrome; pulsatile tinnitus; stroke symptoms
Migraine with aura often first symptom; subcortical strokes; family history; cognitive decline
differential.tests: MRI shows characteristic WMH (anterior temporal, external capsule); NOTCH3 mutation

differential.features: Stroke-like episodes not following vascular territory; seizures; elevated lactate; short stature
differential.tests: MRI (non-vascular stroke pattern); genetic testing; muscle biopsy

disposition.criteria: Typical aura pattern confirmed; no stroke symptoms; pain controlled; able to tolerate PO; follow-up arranged; contraceptive counseling if needed
Prolonged aura (>60 min) requiring observation; status migrainosus requiring IV therapy; first aura with abnormal imaging requiring further workup; hemiplegic migraine with prolonged weakness
Migrainous infarction (stroke occurring during typical aura); hemodynamic instability; severe refractory status migrainosus requiring ketamine infusion
Stroke mimicking aura requiring thrombectomy evaluation; complex hemiplegic migraine requiring tertiary headache center
New diagnosis: 2-4 weeks; Stable on prevention: 3-6 months; After preventive change: 4-8 weeks

Trigeminal Neuralgia.title: Trigeminal Neuralgia
Trigeminal Neuralgia.scope: ** Diagnosis, differentiation of classic (idiopathic) vs secondary TN (MS, tumor, vascular), medical and surgical management. Covers typical TN (TN1), atypical TN (TN2), and secondary TN.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Baseline before carbamazepine (bone marrow suppression risk); exclude infection
Baseline renal/hepatic function before carbamazepine; SIADH risk
Screen Asian patients before carbamazepine/oxcarbazepine (SJS/TEN risk)

Extended Workup.rationale: Inflammatory causes; giant cell arteritis if age >50 with atypical features
SLE or connective tissue disease with trigeminal involvement
Endemic areas; if facial numbness or other cranial nerve involvement

Rare/Specialized.item: CSF analysis (cell count, protein, oligoclonal bands)

Essential/First-line.item: MRI Brain with trigeminal protocol (3T preferred; CISS/FIESTA sequences)
Essential/First-line.target: Neurovascular compression (SCA, AICA); rule out MS plaques, tumor, other structural cause
Confirm vascular loop (SCA, AICA) compressing trigeminal nerve

Extended.target: Rule out schwannoma, meningioma, epidermoid cyst

Rare/Specialized.item: Trigeminal reflex testing (blink reflex, masseter reflex)

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology referral for diagnosis confirmation, medication optimization, and long-term management
Neurosurgery consultation for surgical evaluation if medication refractory or vascular compression on imaging
Pain management referral for multidisciplinary approach and interventional options
Oral surgery or dentistry to rule out dental pathology mimicking TN
Neuro-ophthalmology if V1 involvement with corneal reflex concerns
Psychiatry or psychology for coping strategies given chronic severe pain and depression risk
Ophthalmology for corneal protection if reduced corneal sensation after procedure

Patient Instructions.item: Avoid known triggers such as cold wind, touching face, eating, brushing teeth, or talking when possible
Return immediately if facial weakness, hearing changes, or fever develop after procedure (may indicate serious complication)
Do not stop carbamazepine or oxcarbazepine abruptly as this may cause rebound pain or seizures
Report any skin rash, mouth sores, or fever immediately (may indicate serious drug reaction SJS/TEN)
Monitor for signs of low sodium (confusion, nausea, headache, muscle cramps) especially in first weeks on carbamazepine/oxcarbazepine
Report any easy bruising, bleeding, or frequent infections (may indicate bone marrow suppression)
Keep a pain diary to track triggers, severity, and medication effectiveness
Protect eye on affected side if corneal sensation reduced after surgery (use lubricating drops, protective eyewear)
Soft diet may reduce triggered attacks during flares

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Avoid extreme cold or wind to face (use scarf or mask in cold weather)
Maintain good dental hygiene to prevent dental infections that may worsen or mimic TN
Stress reduction techniques (meditation, relaxation) as stress can exacerbate attacks
Use lukewarm water for face washing; avoid very cold water
Consider electric toothbrush with soft bristles to minimize trigger stimulation
Eat softer foods during flare periods to reduce chewing-triggered attacks
Avoid alcohol which may interact with medications and worsen symptoms
Join TN support groups for coping strategies and emotional support

Bell's Palsy.scope: ** Acute unilateral peripheral facial nerve palsy of presumed idiopathic etiology. Covers initial evaluation, treatment, and follow-up. Excludes Ramsay Hunt syndrome (herpes zoster oticus), central facial palsy, bilateral facial palsy, and secondary causes.

Extended Workup.rationale: Endemic areas or tick exposure; bilateral palsy

Referrals & Consults.item: Ophthalmology referral urgently if corneal involvement, severe lagophthalmos, or eye pain concerning for exposure keratopathy
Neurology referral if atypical features, no improvement by 3-4 weeks, or concern for central etiology
ENT/Otolaryngology referral if Ramsay Hunt suspected, recurrent palsy, or consideration of surgical decompression
Physical therapy referral for facial rehabilitation, particularly if incomplete recovery or synkinesis
Plastic surgery/Oculoplastic referral for chronic lagophthalmos requiring surgical intervention (gold weight, tarsorrhaphy)

Patient Instructions.item: Return immediately for eye pain, redness, or vision changes which may indicate corneal injury from exposure
Return if facial weakness worsens after initial improvement or new symptoms develop (numbness, hearing loss, other weakness)
Protect affected eye from wind, dust, and debris with glasses or moisture chamber during recovery
Use artificial tears frequently during the day and lubricating ointment at night; tape eye closed if unable to fully close
Most patients (70-85%) recover completely; recovery typically begins within 3 weeks and completes within 3-4 months
Do not discontinue steroids abruptly as this may cause adrenal insufficiency; complete the full taper as prescribed
Facial exercises may help recovery; gently massage face and practice facial movements in mirror several times daily

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Adequate sleep and stress management as viral reactivation may be triggered by stress and immunosuppression
Avoid extreme cold and wind exposure to face during recovery period to prevent irritation
Diabetic patients should maintain strict glycemic control as hyperglycemia worsens prognosis and slows recovery
Avoid driving if unable to fully close eye or if vision is significantly impaired

Vertigo Evaluation.title: Vertigo Evaluation
Vertigo Evaluation.scope: ** Evaluation of acute and chronic vertigo including differentiation of peripheral vs central causes. Covers BPPV, vestibular neuritis, labyrinthitis, and Meniere's disease workup. Includes red flag identification for posterior circulation stroke. Excludes presyncope, orthostatic hypotension, and cardiac causes of dizziness.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Hypoglycemia can cause dizziness/lightheadedness mimicking vertigo
Electrolyte disturbance can cause dizziness; assess renal function
Thyroid dysfunction can cause vestibular symptoms

Extended Workup.rationale: Screen for diabetes if neuropathy suspected contributing to imbalance
Deficiency causes peripheral neuropathy affecting balance
Elevated in vasculitis, autoimmune inner ear disease
Vascular risk assessment if central cause suspected

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Specific marker for autoimmune inner ear disease
Endemic area with vestibular and facial nerve involvement
Confirmatory test if RPR positive; otosyphilis

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology consultation for central vertigo evaluation when HINTS exam suggests central lesion or stroke suspected
ENT/Otology referral for refractory BPPV, Meniere's disease management, or hearing loss evaluation
Vestibular physical therapy for vestibular rehabilitation and balance retraining after acute vertigo resolves
Audiology for formal hearing assessment and vestibular function testing (VNG, VEMP)
Neuro-ophthalmology if ocular motor abnormalities persist or skew deviation concerning for brainstem lesion
Stroke neurology for urgent evaluation if HINTS-plus exam suggests posterior circulation stroke
Cardiology if presyncope suspected or arrhythmia contributing to dizziness

Patient Instructions.item: Return immediately if vertigo associated with new headache, diplopia, dysarthria, dysphagia, or weakness (signs of stroke)
Return immediately if sudden hearing loss occurs which requires urgent treatment within 72 hours
Avoid driving, operating machinery, or working at heights until vertigo resolves completely due to fall and accident risk
Use assistive devices (cane, walker) if balance impaired to prevent falls
Perform Brandt-Daroff exercises twice daily as instructed if diagnosed with BPPV
Keep head elevated 30-45 degrees when sleeping for 24-48 hours after Epley maneuver (controversial but commonly recommended)
Avoid sudden head movements and rapid position changes which may trigger vertigo
Maintain hydration and avoid skipping meals as dehydration and hypoglycemia can worsen symptoms

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Sodium restriction (<2000 mg/day) if Meniere's disease diagnosed to reduce attack frequency
Caffeine reduction or elimination as caffeine can exacerbate vestibular symptoms
Alcohol avoidance as alcohol directly affects vestibular function and can trigger episodes
Stress management through relaxation techniques as stress can trigger vestibular migraine and Meniere's attacks
Regular sleep schedule as sleep deprivation can worsen vestibular symptoms
Fall prevention measures including removing throw rugs, installing grab bars, adequate lighting at home
Smoking cessation to reduce vascular risk factors that contribute to central vertigo

Syncope Evaluation.title: Syncope Evaluation
Syncope Evaluation.scope: ** Comprehensive evaluation of transient loss of consciousness (TLOC) due to cerebral hypoperfusion. Covers vasovagal/reflex syncope, orthostatic hypotension, cardiac arrhythmias, and neurologic mimics. Includes risk stratification, diagnostic workup, and management. Excludes seizure-related loss of consciousness (see Seizure plan), stroke, and metabolic causes of altered mental status.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Rule out arrhythmia, conduction abnormality, ischemia, cardiomyopathy (prolonged QT, Brugada, WPW, ARVC)
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal sinus rhythm; QTc <450 ms (M), <460 ms (F); no preexcitation or Brugada pattern

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Rule out hypoglycemia as cause of altered consciousness
Evaluate for anemia causing reduced oxygen delivery; infection
Electrolyte abnormalities can cause arrhythmias or contribute to syncope
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal Na, K, Mg, Ca, glucose, creatinine

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Cardiac ischemia as cause of syncope; elevated in PE, aortic dissection
Diagnose orthostatic hypotension (BP drop >20/10 mmHg or HR increase >30 bpm)
Essential/Core Labs.target: No significant change; BP stable within 3 min of standing

Extended Workup.rationale: Screen for heart failure; elevated in cardiac syncope
Thyroid dysfunction contributing to arrhythmias or autonomic dysfunction
Tissue hypoperfusion; consider if prolonged LOC or concern for cardiogenic shock
Ectopic pregnancy can present with syncope; all reproductive-age women

Rare/Specialized.target: Normal increase with standing; absence suggests autonomic failure
>10 mcg/dL (AM); consider ACTH stim test if borderline

Referrals & Consults.item: Cardiology consultation for arrhythmia evaluation, structural heart disease assessment, or device implantation consideration
Electrophysiology referral for documented arrhythmias requiring ablation, pacemaker or ICD evaluation, or unexplained high-risk syncope
Neurology consultation if seizure-syncope differentiation unclear, autonomic testing needed, or neurological symptoms present
Autonomic disorders specialist for recurrent orthostatic hypotension, suspected pure autonomic failure, or multiple system atrophy
Driving evaluation per state regulations for commercial drivers or recurrent unexplained syncope affecting driving ability
Psychiatry referral if psychogenic pseudosyncope suspected based on atypical features and normal workup
Fall prevention physical therapy for elderly patients with recurrent syncope to reduce injury risk
Occupational health evaluation for patients in safety-sensitive occupations (pilots, heavy machinery operators, commercial drivers)

Patient Instructions.item: Return immediately if syncope recurs, especially with chest pain, palpitations, shortness of breath, or exercise (may indicate cardiac cause requiring urgent evaluation)
Return immediately if prolonged confusion, seizure activity, tongue biting, or urinary incontinence occurs with loss of consciousness (suggests seizure rather than syncope)
Do NOT drive until cleared by physician due to risk of syncope while operating a vehicle; specific restrictions depend on diagnosis and state law
Avoid prolonged standing, hot environments, and dehydration which are common triggers for vasovagal syncope
Learn to recognize prodromal symptoms (lightheadedness, warmth, nausea, tunnel vision) and immediately sit or lie down to prevent injury
Perform physical counterpressure maneuvers (leg crossing, squatting, handgrip) at first sign of prodrome to abort vasovagal episode
Rise slowly from lying to sitting to standing (staged position changes) to prevent orthostatic syncope
Maintain adequate hydration (2-3 L daily) and salt intake (unless contraindicated) to support blood volume
Keep a symptom diary noting triggers, prodrome, circumstances, duration of LOC, and recovery to aid diagnosis
Wear medical alert identification if recurrent syncope diagnosis confirmed

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Avoid known triggers including prolonged standing, crowded/hot environments, excessive alcohol, and large meals
Increase oral fluid intake to 2-3 liters daily to maintain intravascular volume and reduce syncope frequency
Increase dietary salt intake to 6-10 g/day if no contraindication (hypertension, heart failure, CKD) to expand plasma volume
Wear waist-high compression stockings (30-40 mmHg) during daytime to reduce venous pooling
Avoid sudden postural changes; use staged position changes (lie-sit-stand with 1-2 min at each stage)
Review and minimize medications that contribute to hypotension (diuretics, antihypertensives, alpha-blockers, nitrates, psychiatric medications)
Avoid excessive heat exposure including hot showers, saunas, and hot tubs which cause vasodilation
Sleep with head of bed elevated 10-20 degrees to reduce nocturnal natriuresis and improve morning orthostatic tolerance
Moderate regular aerobic exercise to improve vascular tone and reduce vasovagal susceptibility; avoid deconditioning
Alcohol moderation or avoidance as alcohol causes vasodilation and impairs autonomic reflexes

disposition.criteria: Low-risk features: isolated vasovagal syncope with clear trigger, normal ECG, normal cardiac exam, no significant injury, reliable follow-up; San Francisco Syncope Rule negative OR Canadian Syncope Risk Score very low/low risk
Intermediate risk: unexplained syncope with normal initial workup; awaiting troponin results; awaiting echocardiogram; single syncopal episode without high-risk features

High-risk features: abnormal ECG, structural heart disease, heart failure, exertional syncope, syncope causing significant injury, recurrent syncope of unclear etiology, syncope with chest pain or dyspnea
Very high-risk: hemodynamic instability, documented malignant arrhythmia, syncope with ongoing ischemia, severe bradycardia requiring pacing, PE with hypotension
Low-risk syncope discharged from ED: cardiology/neurology follow-up within 1-2 weeks; recurrent vasovagal syncope: 2-4 weeks; post-device implantation: per device protocol

Carpal Tunnel Syndrome.title: Carpal Tunnel Syndrome
Carpal Tunnel Syndrome.scope: ** Evaluation and management of carpal tunnel syndrome from initial presentation through conservative treatment, injection therapy, and surgical referral. Covers clinical diagnosis, electrodiagnostic testing, severity grading, and treatment options. For acute median nerve injury or severe CTS with thenar atrophy, early surgical referral is indicated.

Referrals & Consults.item: Hand surgery or orthopedic surgery referral for carpal tunnel release evaluation when conservative therapy fails or severe CTS present
Electrodiagnostic medicine/neurology for NCS/EMG to confirm diagnosis and grade severity before surgical intervention
Occupational medicine for workplace ergonomic assessment and work restrictions if occupational risk factors present
Physical/occupational therapy for nerve gliding exercises, ergonomic training, and activity modification
Rheumatology referral if inflammatory arthritis suspected as underlying cause (RA, gout)
Endocrinology for diabetes optimization or hypothyroidism management if contributing to CTS
Primary care for management of modifiable risk factors (diabetes, obesity, hypothyroidism)
Pain management if refractory neuropathic symptoms despite treatment

Patient Instructions.item: Wear wrist splint nightly in neutral position for minimum 4-6 weeks; may wear during day if symptoms persist with activities
Avoid prolonged wrist flexion or extension (typing, gripping tools, driving) as this increases carpal tunnel pressure
Take frequent breaks during repetitive hand activities (every 30-60 minutes) to rest wrists
Perform nerve gliding exercises as instructed by therapist to improve median nerve mobility
Apply ice for 10-15 minutes if wrist swelling present; avoid direct ice contact with skin
Report worsening numbness, weakness in thumb, or dropping objects (may indicate progression requiring surgery)
Avoid sleeping with wrists curled under pillow; maintain neutral wrist position during sleep
If pregnant, symptoms often improve after delivery; conservative management preferred during pregnancy
After corticosteroid injection, temporary increase in symptoms may occur first 24-48 hours before improvement
Post-surgical: Keep incision clean and dry; elevate hand; start motion as directed; full grip strength recovery may take 3-6 months

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Optimize glycemic control (HbA1c <7%) as diabetes worsens nerve function and CTS outcomes
Weight loss if overweight/obese as obesity is modifiable risk factor for CTS
Ergonomic workstation setup: keyboard at elbow height, wrists neutral, avoid resting wrists on hard surfaces
Use ergonomic keyboard, mouse, and tools if occupation involves repetitive hand use
Smoking cessation to improve microvascular circulation and nerve healing
Avoid prolonged use of vibrating tools or take breaks every 15-30 minutes when using such equipment
Reduce caffeine and alcohol intake as these may worsen paresthesias in some patients
Treat underlying thyroid disease as hypothyroidism contributes to CTS through tissue edema
Stretch and warm up hands before repetitive activities
Vitamin B6 supplementation not recommended (evidence does not support benefit; high doses cause neuropathy)

Referrals & Consults.item: Spine surgery (neurosurgery or orthopedic spine) consult STAT for cauda equina syndrome, progressive motor deficit, or myelopathic signs
Spine surgery consult URGENT for significant weakness (<4/5) or radiculopathy refractory to 6+ weeks conservative treatment
Physical therapy for core strengthening, McKenzie exercises, nerve gliding, and posture training
Pain management/Interventional spine for epidural steroid injections if conservative treatment fails after 4-6 weeks
PM&R (Physical Medicine & Rehabilitation) for comprehensive spine rehabilitation program
EMG/NCS referral to confirm radiculopathy level and exclude peripheral neuropathy or plexopathy (optimal timing 3-4 weeks after symptom onset)
Oncology consult for suspected spinal metastases or pathologic fracture
Infectious disease consult for suspected epidural abscess, discitis, or vertebral osteomyelitis
Rheumatology for suspected inflammatory spondyloarthropathy (ankylosing spondylitis, psoriatic arthritis)
Occupational therapy for ergonomic assessment, workplace modifications, and ADL training
Psychology/Pain psychology for chronic pain management, CBT for pain, catastrophizing assessment
Neurology for atypical presentation, polyradiculopathy, or suspected inflammatory/infectious etiology
Social work for disability assistance, return-to-work planning, and insurance navigation

Patient Instructions.item: Return to ED IMMEDIATELY if bladder or bowel incontinence, inability to urinate, saddle area numbness, or bilateral leg weakness (may indicate cauda equina syndrome)
Return to ED if fever develops with back/neck pain (may indicate infection)
Return if weakness is progressing or you are unable to lift foot/hand (progressive motor deficit requires urgent evaluation)
Most radiculopathy improves with conservative treatment over 4-6 weeks; surgery is rarely needed
Stay active within pain limits; prolonged bed rest (>1-2 days) is not recommended and may delay recovery
Apply ice for first 48-72 hours (20 min on/off), then switch to heat for muscle relaxation
Avoid heavy lifting, twisting, and prolonged sitting; use proper body mechanics
Sleep with pillow between knees (side) or under knees (back) to reduce spine stress
For cervical radiculopathy: avoid prolonged neck flexion (looking down at phone); use cervical pillow
Do not stop gabapentin/pregabalin abruptly - taper under medical guidance to avoid withdrawal
Neuropathic pain medications (gabapentin, pregabalin) take 2-4 weeks to reach full effect
Physical therapy exercises should be continued daily at home for best outcomes
Do not drive while taking opioids or sedating muscle relaxants
Follow up with primary care or neurology in 2-4 weeks to assess treatment response

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Smoking cessation to improve disc nutrition and surgical outcomes (smoking accelerates disc degeneration)
Weight loss if BMI >25 to reduce spinal load and improve symptoms
Core strengthening exercises to support spine (plank, bird-dog, bridges)
Proper lifting technique: bend at knees, keep load close, avoid twisting
Ergonomic workstation setup: monitor at eye level, lumbar support, feet flat
Take breaks every 30-60 minutes if seated for prolonged periods
Maintain good posture: shoulders back, chin tucked, avoid forward head position
Regular low-impact exercise (walking, swimming, stationary bike) to maintain fitness
Avoid high-impact activities (running, jumping) during acute phase
Yoga or Pilates (modified) for flexibility and core strength after acute phase resolves
Use supportive mattress; avoid sleeping on stomach
Manage stress as tension can worsen muscle spasm and pain perception
Glycemic control if diabetic (HbA1c <7%) to reduce neuropathic component and improve surgical outcomes

NSAIDs effective for acute radiculopathy pain
