disposition.criteria: No red flags present; pain controlled with oral medications; able to ambulate; normal bladder function; motor strength ≥4/5 and stable; reliable follow-up arranged within 2-4 weeks

Severe pain requiring IV analgesia; significant motor weakness (≤3/5) requiring close monitoring; need for IV antibiotics (suspected infection); inability to ambulate safely; need for urgent MRI not available as outpatient

Rapidly progressive motor deficit requiring emergent surgery; hemodynamic instability from sepsis (spinal infection); airway compromise (high cervical pathology); post-operative monitoring for complex spine surgery
Cauda equina syndrome (bladder dysfunction, saddle anesthesia, bilateral weakness); progressive motor deficit despite steroids; epidural abscess with neurologic deficit
Spine surgery not available; MRI not available for emergent imaging; interventional spine services not available for ESI when indicated

Small Fiber Neuropathy.title: Small Fiber Neuropathy
Small Fiber Neuropathy.scope: ** Diagnosis and management of small fiber neuropathy presenting with painful sensory and/or autonomic symptoms with normal or near-normal nerve conduction studies. Includes length-dependent and non-length-dependent (ganglionopathy) patterns. Covers etiologic workup for treatable causes, symptomatic pain management, and autonomic symptom treatment.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Diabetes and prediabetes are most common causes of SFN
Current glycemic status; impaired fasting glucose
Impaired glucose tolerance causes SFN even with normal HbA1c
Renal function; medication dosing; uremic neuropathy
B12 deficiency causes SFN; common and treatable
Sjogren syndrome is common cause of SFN (up to 40% of SFN)

Extended Workup.rationale: More sensitive for B12 deficiency if B12 borderline (200-400)
Celiac disease causes SFN even without GI symptoms
Both deficiency and excess cause neuropathy
Sjogren syndrome if clinical suspicion high and serology negative

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Fabry disease screening (X-linked; consider in males and females)
Confirm Fabry disease if enzyme low or high clinical suspicion
Hereditary transthyretin amyloidosis; early SFN with autonomic symptoms

Rare/Specialized.item: Fat pad or skin biopsy (Congo red)
Rare/Specialized.rationale: Amyloidosis if suspected (autonomic features, cardiomyopathy, CTS)
Paraneoplastic sensory ganglionopathy (anti-Hu) if rapid onset
Objective dry eye for Sjogren diagnosis

Essential/First-line.target: Normal or near-normal (SFN spares large fibers)

Essential/First-line.item: Skin biopsy (3mm punch at distal leg and thigh)
Essential/First-line.timing: After NCS shows normal large fiber function
Essential/First-line.target: Reduced IENFD below normative threshold for age/sex/site

Extended.target: Normal sweat volumes at all sites
Normal electrochemical skin conductance hands and feet
Normal cardiovagal, adrenergic, and sudomotor function
No excessive HR rise; no orthostatic hypotension

Extended.timing: Thermal threshold testing; research and specialized centers
Global sudomotor evaluation if QSART equivocal
Non-invasive small fiber assessment; research tool
Extended.target: Normal corneal nerve fiber density and length

Rare/Specialized.timing: If large fiber involvement suspected; atypical features
Rare/Specialized.target: Normal (SFN spares motor and large sensory fibers)
Normal dorsal root ganglia; no dorsal column signal
No nerve enlargement or signal abnormality

Rare/Specialized.timing: Sarcoidosis or malignancy suspected; paraneoplastic evaluation
Cardiac amyloidosis evaluation if echo abnormal

Referrals & Consults.item: Neuromuscular specialist for skin biopsy interpretation and complex SFN management
Rheumatology if Sjogren's, lupus, or other connective tissue disease suspected
Endocrinology if diabetes/prediabetes for glycemic optimization and metabolic management
Genetics counselor if hereditary etiology suspected (Fabry, TTR amyloidosis, SCN9A channelopathies)
Gastroenterology for celiac confirmation, gastroparesis management, or liver biopsy if amyloid suspected
Cardiology if TTR amyloidosis suspected or autonomic symptoms with cardiac involvement
Pain management for refractory neuropathic pain and interventional options (spinal cord stimulation)
Physical therapy for balance training, strengthening, and fall prevention
Autonomic disorders specialist if complex autonomic symptoms (POTS, orthostatic hypotension)
Psychiatry/psychology for chronic pain coping and comorbid depression/anxiety management
Hematology/oncology if amyloidosis confirmed for staging and treatment

Patient Instructions.item: Report any new weakness, gait difficulty, or falls as these may indicate progression to large fiber involvement
Monitor for signs of infection in feet (redness, warmth, drainage) if sensation is impaired
Keep a pain diary to track triggers, severity, and medication response
Rise slowly from sitting or lying to prevent falls from orthostatic hypotension
Increase salt and fluid intake (2-3L/day, 6-10g sodium) if orthostatic hypotension present (unless contraindicated)
Wear compression stockings before rising in the morning if orthostatic hypotension diagnosed
Take all prescribed pain medications as directed; do not stop gabapentinoids or SNRIs abruptly
Avoid excessive heat exposure which can worsen symptoms; stay hydrated in warm weather
Return if severe headache, vision changes, or syncope develop (may indicate medication side effects or disease progression)

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Strict glycemic control (HbA1c <7% or <5.7% if prediabetes) to prevent progression; lifestyle modifications first
Alcohol cessation as alcohol independently causes and worsens small fiber neuropathy
Smoking cessation as smoking impairs nerve regeneration and worsens outcomes
Regular low-impact exercise (swimming, stationary bike, walking) to improve pain and maintain function
Healthy diet (Mediterranean or DASH) to optimize metabolic health and reduce inflammation
Weight management as metabolic syndrome is associated with SFN
Sleep hygiene to improve sleep quality; chronic pain worsens with poor sleep
Stress reduction techniques (mindfulness, meditation) as stress can amplify pain perception
Fall prevention with home safety evaluation given proprioceptive deficits and orthostatic hypotension
Avoid B6 (pyridoxine) supplementation above RDA (1.3-2 mg/day) as excess causes neuropathy

Myasthenia Gravis - Outpatient Managemen.title: Myasthenia Gravis - Outpatient Management
Myasthenia Gravis - Outpatient Managemen.scope: ** Outpatient diagnosis, management, and monitoring of myasthenia gravis in adults. Covers antibody-positive (AChR, MuSK, LRP4) and seronegative MG, ocular and generalized subtypes, pyridostigmine optimization, immunotherapy initiation and monitoring, thymectomy evaluation, and crisis prevention. Excludes myasthenic crisis (see "Myasthenia Gravis - Exacerbation/Crisis"), Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS), congenital myasthenic syndromes, and drug-induced myasthenia.

Increases sensitivity when combined with binding antibody
Additional AChR antibody; may be positive when binding negative

Referrals & Consults.item: Neuromuscular specialist/MG center for diagnosis confirmation, treatment optimization, and clinical trial consideration
Thoracic surgery consult for thymectomy evaluation in AChR+ generalized MG age 18-65 years without thymoma, or any patient with thymoma
Pulmonology consult for baseline pulmonary function testing and ongoing respiratory monitoring in patients with respiratory symptoms
Neuro-ophthalmology for diplopia management, prism prescription, or ptosis surgery evaluation in stable ocular MG
Speech therapy for swallow evaluation given bulbar symptoms and aspiration risk assessment
Physical therapy for generalized weakness to maintain function and prevent deconditioning
Occupational therapy for ADL assessment and energy conservation strategies given fatigable weakness
Rheumatology if concurrent autoimmune disease suspected (thyroid, lupus, rheumatoid arthritis)
Infusion center for IVIg, rituximab, eculizumab, or other IV immunotherapy administration
High-risk OB for pregnancy planning in women with MG given medication adjustments and delivery planning
Endocrinology for steroid-induced diabetes, osteoporosis, or adrenal insufficiency management
Social work for disability planning, MG Foundation resources, and insurance navigation for expensive biologics
Psychiatry for depression or anxiety related to chronic illness or steroid side effects

Patient Instructions.item: Return immediately if worsening weakness, breathing difficulty, or difficulty swallowing develops (may indicate crisis requiring hospitalization)
Carry MG medical alert card or bracelet listing diagnosis and medications to avoid (aminoglycosides, fluoroquinolones, beta-blockers, magnesium)
Do not stop prednisone or immunosuppressants abruptly; sudden discontinuation may trigger exacerbation or adrenal crisis
Take pyridostigmine 30-60 minutes before meals to improve swallowing and reduce choking risk during eating
Report fever or signs of infection promptly as immunosuppression increases infection risk and infection can trigger MG exacerbation
Avoid extreme heat as high temperatures worsen neuromuscular transmission and increase weakness
Do not drive if diplopia or ptosis impairs vision; symptoms may fluctuate throughout the day
Avoid overexertion; pace activities throughout the day with rest periods to manage fatigable weakness
Report new medications (including over-the-counter) to neurologist before taking, as many common drugs worsen MG
Women: Discuss pregnancy plans with MG specialist in advance as medication adjustments are needed before conception
Contact Myasthenia Gravis Foundation of America (www.myasthenia.org) for patient support, educational resources, and community
Report symptoms of cholinergic overdose: excessive secretions, diarrhea, cramping, muscle twitching, bradycardia (reduce pyridostigmine dose)

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Medication reconciliation before any new prescription to avoid MG-exacerbating drugs; bring medication list to all appointments
Avoid live vaccines while on immunosuppression (azathioprine, mycophenolate, rituximab, high-dose steroids); inactivated vaccines are safe
Annual influenza vaccine (inactivated) to prevent respiratory infections that can trigger exacerbation
Pneumococcal vaccination (PCV15 or PCV20 + PPSV23) before starting immunosuppression
Aspiration precautions including upright positioning during and after meals, small bites, and avoiding mixed textures if bulbar symptoms present
Energy conservation techniques including pacing activities, scheduled rest periods, and prioritizing important tasks for morning
Avoid smoking as respiratory infections worsen MG and smoking reduces treatment efficacy
Limit alcohol intake as it can worsen weakness and interact with medications
Stress management as psychological stress can trigger MG exacerbations
Good sleep hygiene as fatigue and sleep deprivation worsen MG symptoms
Wear medical alert identification listing MG diagnosis and medications to avoid in emergencies
Weight management to reduce respiratory load and minimize steroid side effects

disposition.criteria: Stable ocular or mild generalized MG; FVC >60% and stable; able to swallow safely; no respiratory symptoms; reliable follow-up

Moderate-severe worsening not requiring ICU; initiation of high-dose steroids with IVIg/PLEX coverage; significant bulbar symptoms with aspiration risk; FVC 30-60% and declining; new diagnosis with moderate severity
FVC <30% or rapidly declining; NIF weaker than -30 cmH2O; impending respiratory failure; severe bulbar dysfunction with aspiration; need for intubation or BiPAP
Acute worsening of weakness; new respiratory symptoms (dyspnea, orthopnea); difficulty swallowing or speaking; recent infection or medication change with weakness; FVC declining on outpatient checks
Refractory MG not responding to standard therapy; thymectomy evaluation; clinical trial consideration; complex immunotherapy decisions

Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) / Mo.title: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) / Motor Neuron Disease
Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) / Mo.scope: ** Comprehensive outpatient-focused management of ALS including diagnostic workup, El Escorial/Awaji criteria application, disease-modifying therapy (riluzole, edaravone, AMX0035), symptomatic management (sialorrhea, spasticity, pseudobulbar affect, pain, dyspnea), respiratory monitoring with BiPAP timing, nutritional support with PEG timing, multidisciplinary clinic model, and palliative care integration. Excludes primary lateral sclerosis (PLS), progressive muscular atrophy (PMA), and pediatric motor neuron disease.

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology (ALS specialist/multidisciplinary clinic) for diagnosis confirmation, disease-modifying therapy, and comprehensive management coordination
Pulmonology for respiratory function monitoring, BiPAP initiation, and ventilator management decisions
Physical therapy for mobility assessment, strengthening (submaximal), range of motion, and assistive device prescription
Occupational therapy for ADL assessment, adaptive equipment, energy conservation, and home modification
Speech-language pathology for swallow evaluation, communication strategies, and AAC device assessment
Respiratory therapy for BiPAP setup and titration, cough assist training, and secretion management
Nutrition/dietitian for caloric needs assessment, weight optimization, and tube feeding management
Palliative care for symptom management, goals of care discussions, and quality of life optimization
Social work for financial resources (SSDI, Medicaid), caregiver support, and ALS Association resources
Psychiatry/psychology for depression, anxiety, and adjustment disorder common in ALS
Gastroenterology for PEG placement when FVC declining toward 50% or significant dysphagia
Hospice care for end-of-life care when prognosis <6 months and/or patient declines aggressive interventions
Genetic counseling for familial ALS, gene testing interpretation, and family planning implications

Patient Instructions.item: Return immediately for increased shortness of breath, choking episodes, or inability to clear secretions (may indicate respiratory failure requiring urgent intervention)
Return for fever, worsening cough, or change in sputum color (may indicate aspiration pneumonia)
Do not drive if experiencing significant weakness or fatigue that could impair vehicle control
Continue eating foods that are safe to swallow; use thickened liquids if recommended by speech therapy
Use BiPAP as prescribed, even if initially uncomfortable; adherence improves symptoms and survival
Perform prescribed exercises but avoid exhaustion; rest before becoming overly fatigued
Complete advance directives including healthcare proxy, living will, and decisions about mechanical ventilation and feeding tubes
Contact ALS Association (www.als.org) for educational resources, support groups, and equipment loan programs
Attend multidisciplinary ALS clinic visits every 2-3 months for comprehensive care coordination
Consider joining ALS research registries and clinical trials (www.clinicaltrials.gov)

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Aspiration precautions including upright positioning during meals, small bites, and chin-tuck swallowing technique
Energy conservation with scheduled rest periods and prioritization of activities to reduce fatigue
Home safety evaluation to remove fall hazards, install grab bars, and ensure wheelchair accessibility
Maintain optimal nutrition with high-calorie, high-protein diet; weight loss accelerates decline
Sleep with head of bed elevated 30 degrees if using BiPAP or experiencing orthopnea
Smoking cessation is essential to optimize respiratory function and reduce aspiration risk
Limit alcohol as it may worsen weakness, sedation, and respiratory depression
Frequent repositioning if immobile to prevent pressure ulcers
Emotional and spiritual support for patient and caregivers; caregiver burnout is common
Consider assistive technology early (voice banking, eye-tracking devices) before speech becomes unintelligible

disposition.criteria: Acute respiratory failure (FVC <15 mL/kg, pCO2 >50, SpO2 <88% on supplemental O2); aspiration pneumonia with respiratory distress; need for invasive ventilation (if patient desires)

Aspiration pneumonia without respiratory distress; severe dehydration or malnutrition; new bulbar symptoms requiring evaluation; falls with injury

Dystonia.title: Dystonia
Dystonia.scope: ** Diagnosis, classification, workup for secondary causes, and symptomatic management of dystonia. Covers focal (cervical, blepharospasm, writer's cramp), segmental, and generalized forms. Includes evaluation for Wilson's disease, dopa-responsive dystonia, and drug-induced dystonia.

Deficiency causes myelopathy and movement disorders

Referrals & Consults.item: Movement disorders neurology for diagnosis confirmation, classification, and treatment planning
Ophthalmology for slit lamp examination to evaluate for Kayser-Fleischer rings (Wilson's disease workup)
Hepatology if Wilson's disease diagnosed for hepatic management and transplant evaluation if severe
Genetic counseling if genetic dystonia confirmed or suspected (DYT1, DYT6, GCH1)
Neurosurgery consultation for DBS evaluation if medication-refractory
Physical therapy for posture correction, stretching, and range of motion exercises
Occupational therapy for adaptive techniques and assistive devices for ADLs
Speech therapy if oromandibular dystonia, laryngeal dystonia, or cervical dystonia affecting swallowing
Pain management if chronic pain from dystonic posturing not controlled with primary treatment
Psychology/psychiatry for coping strategies, depression/anxiety management related to chronic dystonia

Patient Instructions.item: After botulinum toxin injection: avoid rubbing injection sites; effects develop over 3-14 days and last 10-12 weeks
Report any swallowing difficulty or breathing problems after botulinum toxin injection (may indicate spread)
Use sensory tricks (geste antagoniste) such as touching chin or face which may temporarily reduce cervical dystonia
Return to ED if severe muscle spasms with fever, confusion, or dark urine (possible dystonic storm or rhabdomyolysis)
Continue physical therapy exercises at home to maintain range of motion and prevent contractures
Avoid medications that worsen dystonia: metoclopramide, prochlorperazine, haloperidol, and other dopamine blockers
For Wilson's disease: strict adherence to copper chelation is lifelong; follow dietary copper restrictions
Keep a symptom diary noting triggers, sensory tricks that help, and response to medications

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Stress management with relaxation techniques as stress can exacerbate dystonia
Adequate sleep as fatigue worsens dystonia symptoms
Limit caffeine and stimulants which may worsen tremor/dystonia
Regular gentle exercise (swimming, yoga) to maintain flexibility without overexertion
Ergonomic workstation modifications for task-specific dystonia (writer's cramp, musician's dystonia)
For Wilson's disease: avoid high-copper foods (liver, shellfish, chocolate, nuts, mushrooms) especially during initial treatment
Avoid alcohol especially if on benzodiazepines or with hepatic involvement (Wilson's)
Heat application to affected muscles may provide temporary relief
Support groups for dystonia provide coping strategies and community connection

Patient Instructions.item: Return immediately if sudden worsening of confusion which may indicate stroke, infection, or medication toxicity
If on anti-amyloid therapy (lecanemab, donanemab): return immediately for new headache, visual changes, confusion, or unsteadiness (possible ARIA)
Complete advance directives (living will, healthcare proxy, POLST) while patient has capacity to document preferences for future care
Designate financial power of attorney and consider trust arrangements early while patient can participate
Do not drive until cleared by physician or formal driving evaluation; report diagnosis to DMV per state requirements
Use pill organizers, alarms, or caregiver supervision to ensure medication adherence
Wear medical alert bracelet with diagnosis and emergency contact in case of wandering
Keep environment safe: remove throw rugs, install grab bars, secure stove knobs, lock away dangerous items
Maintain consistent daily routines which help with orientation and reduce anxiety

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Regular aerobic exercise (150 min/week moderate intensity) may slow cognitive decline and improve mood
Mediterranean or MIND diet emphasizing vegetables, berries, fish, whole grains, nuts, and olive oil
Cognitive stimulation through reading, puzzles, music, social activities to support cognitive reserve
Adequate sleep (7-8 hours); treat sleep apnea aggressively as it worsens cognition
Social engagement and meaningful activities to reduce isolation and support emotional well-being
Cardiovascular risk factor control: BP <130/80, A1c <7%, LDL <100 to reduce vascular contribution
Hearing aids for hearing loss which is a modifiable dementia risk factor (Lancet Commission)
Limit alcohol to ≤1 drink daily; excess alcohol accelerates cognitive decline
Smoking cessation to reduce vascular damage and improve overall brain health
Caregiver respite services to prevent burnout; Alzheimer's Association support groups

Lewy Body Dementia.title: Lewy Body Dementia
Lewy Body Dementia.scope: ** Diagnosis based on McKeith criteria (2017), biomarker-supported diagnosis (DaTscan, MIBG), symptomatic management of cognitive, motor, behavioral, and autonomic symptoms. Emphasizes neuroleptic sensitivity and safe treatment approaches. Covers both pure DLB and Parkinson's disease dementia (PDD) overlap.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Infection screen; anemia contributing to cognitive changes
Hyponatremia, uremia, hypercalcemia as causes of confusion
Hypothyroidism is reversible cause of cognitive impairment
Deficiency can cause cognitive impairment and parkinsonism
Diabetes affects cognition and autonomic function
UTI common cause of acute confusion in elderly

Extended Workup.rationale: Deficiency associated with falls and cognitive decline

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Family history or early-onset; GBA mutations increase DLB risk

Essential/First-line.target: Relative preservation of medial temporal lobes (vs AD); rule out structural causes
Rule out mass, hemorrhage, hydrocephalus

Extended.timing: Diagnostic uncertainty; differentiating DLB from AD
Extended.target: Reduced dopamine transporter uptake in putamen (indicative biomarker)

Extended.timing: Differentiate DLB from AD; supports diagnosis

Extended.target: Posterior occipital hypometabolism with cingulate island sign (supportive biomarker)
Posterior slow-wave activity with periodic fluctuations (supportive)

Rare/Specialized.target: Less tau deposition than AD for similar dementia severity

Referrals & Consults.item: Cognitive/behavioral neurology for diagnosis confirmation using McKeith criteria and treatment planning
Movement disorders specialist if motor symptoms prominent or considering dopaminergic therapy
Neuropsychology for comprehensive cognitive testing to establish baseline and differentiate from AD
Geriatric psychiatry for behavioral symptoms, medication management, and capacity evaluation
Sleep medicine for polysomnography to confirm REM sleep behavior disorder (indicative biomarker)
Occupational therapy for ADL assessment, cognitive strategies, and home safety evaluation

Social work for caregiver support, community resources, and long-term care planning

Patient Instructions.item: CRITICAL: Avoid all typical antipsychotics and most atypical antipsychotics - severe sensitivity can cause parkinsonism, rigidity, and death
Carry a medication alert card listing "Lewy Body Dementia - Neuroleptic Sensitivity" for all healthcare encounters
Report visual hallucinations immediately as these may indicate disease progression or medication effect
Rise slowly from sitting or lying to prevent falls from orthostatic hypotension
Implement safety measures for REM sleep behavior disorder: padded bed rails, mattress on floor, remove sharp objects from bedside
Complete advance directives while patient has capacity to document wishes for future care
Do not drive due to fluctuating attention, visual-spatial deficits, and hallucinations
Return immediately if sudden worsening of confusion, falls, or inability to walk (may indicate medication effect or infection)

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Fall prevention: remove home hazards, adequate lighting, grab bars, non-slip surfaces due to high fall risk
AVOID medications that worsen symptoms: anticholinergics, antihistamines (diphenhydramine), sleep aids (Benadryl, Tylenol PM)
AVOID antiemetics: metoclopramide, prochlorperazine, promethazine (D2 blocking worsens parkinsonism)
Regular physical exercise as tolerated to maintain mobility and reduce fall risk
Structured daily routine with consistent sleep-wake times helps with fluctuating cognition
Adequate lighting and avoid overstimulation which may trigger hallucinations
Simplify environment and reduce visual clutter to minimize misperceptions
Caregiver education about fluctuating cognition, which is characteristic and not willful
Treat sleep apnea if present as it worsens cognition and autonomic dysfunction

Vascular Dementia.title: Vascular Dementia
Vascular Dementia.scope: ** Diagnosis using NINDS-AIREN and DSM-5 criteria, neuroimaging evaluation for strategic infarcts and white matter disease, vascular risk factor modification, secondary stroke prevention, cholinesterase inhibitors for cognitive symptoms, and management of post-stroke depression, apathy, and behavioral symptoms. Primarily outpatient-focused with coverage for ED and hospital presentations.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Metabolic causes of confusion; renal function for medication dosing
Hypothyroidism is reversible cause of cognitive impairment
Deficiency causes reversible cognitive decline and may worsen vascular dementia
Deficiency contributes to hyperhomocysteinemia and cognitive impairment
Diabetes is major vascular risk factor; assess chronic glucose control
Assess LDL for secondary stroke prevention; target <70 mg/dL
UTI common cause of acute confusion in elderly
Baseline coagulation; assess if on anticoagulation

Extended Workup.rationale: Elevated levels increase stroke risk and contribute to vascular dementia
Independent cardiovascular risk marker; elevated increases stroke risk
Inflammatory marker; elevated predicts vascular events
Deficiency associated with cognitive decline and vascular disease

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology/Cognitive neurology for diagnosis confirmation, differentiation from AD, and treatment planning
Neuropsychology for formal cognitive testing to characterize executive dysfunction and memory profile
Cardiology for atrial fibrillation management, anticoagulation decisions, and heart failure optimization
Vascular surgery consultation for symptomatic carotid stenosis ≥50% to evaluate for endarterectomy
Physical therapy for gait training, balance assessment, and fall prevention given motor involvement
Occupational therapy for ADL assessment, cognitive strategies, and home safety evaluation
Speech therapy for communication strategies, cognitive-linguistic exercises, and swallowing evaluation if dysphagia
Social work for caregiver support resources, community services, and long-term care planning
Geriatric psychiatry for behavioral symptoms, depression management, and capacity evaluation
Registered dietitian for Mediterranean/DASH diet counseling and sodium restriction education
Smoking cessation program with pharmacotherapy for current smokers
Sleep medicine for obstructive sleep apnea evaluation and CPAP initiation if indicated
Palliative care for advanced vascular dementia symptom management and goals of care discussions

Patient Instructions.item: Call 911 immediately if new stroke symptoms develop (sudden weakness, speech difficulty, vision changes)
Return immediately if sudden worsening of confusion which may indicate new stroke, infection, or delirium
Take all medications as prescribed especially antiplatelet/anticoagulant and statin which prevent further strokes
Complete advance directives (living will, healthcare proxy, POLST) while patient has capacity
Do not drive if cognitive impairment affects judgment or reaction time; formal driving evaluation may be needed
Use pill organizers, alarms, or caregiver supervision to ensure medication adherence
Check blood pressure at home regularly; notify provider if consistently >140/90 or <90/60
Wear medical alert bracelet with diagnosis and emergency contact in case of wandering or emergency
Keep environment safe: remove throw rugs, install grab bars, ensure adequate lighting, secure stove knobs

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Blood pressure target <130/80 mmHg to reduce progression and prevent further strokes (SPRINT-MIND data)
LDL target <70 mg/dL with high-intensity statin for secondary vascular prevention
Smoking cessation immediately; reduces stroke risk by 50% within 1 year of quitting
Mediterranean or MIND diet emphasizing vegetables, berries, fish, whole grains, nuts, and olive oil
Limit sodium to <2300 mg/day (ideally <1500 mg if hypertensive) to improve blood pressure control
Limit alcohol to ≤1 drink daily as excess alcohol increases stroke risk and worsens cognition
Regular aerobic exercise (150 min/week moderate intensity) to improve cardiovascular health and cognition
Treat obstructive sleep apnea with CPAP as OSA worsens vascular risk and cognitive function
Strict glycemic control (HbA1c <7% or individualized 7-8% in frail elderly) to reduce microvascular damage
Social engagement and cognitive stimulation to support cognitive reserve
Weight management with target BMI 18.5-27 kg/m² (less stringent in elderly)
Fall prevention with home safety modifications and assistive devices as needed
CPAP compliance for sleep apnea patients to reduce nocturnal hypoxia and vascular events

Cholinesterase inhibitors for vascular dementia (modest benefit)

Referrals & Consults.item: Behavioral/cognitive neurology for diagnosis confirmation, FTD subtype classification, and treatment guidance
Neuropsychology for comprehensive cognitive testing to establish baseline, characterize deficits, and track progression
Genetic counseling for all patients with suspected FTD given high heritability (30-50% familial); discuss testing implications
Speech-language pathology for language variant PPA evaluation, communication strategies, and swallowing assessment
Geriatric psychiatry for complex behavioral management and psychotropic medication optimization
Social work for caregiver support resources, community services, respite care, and long-term care planning
Occupational therapy for ADL assessment, cognitive strategies, home safety evaluation, and activity structuring
Physical therapy for fall prevention, mobility assessment, and exercise program particularly if motor features present
Palliative care for symptom management and goals of care discussions, especially with advanced disease or ALS overlap
Neuromuscular specialist if motor neuron disease features (weakness, fasciculations, bulbar symptoms) present
Elder law attorney for advance directives, healthcare proxy, conservatorship, and financial planning while capacity exists

Patient Instructions.item: Return immediately if sudden worsening of behavior, new weakness, difficulty breathing, or inability to swallow safely
Complete advance directives (living will, healthcare proxy, POLST) while patient retains capacity; FTD can progress rapidly
Designate durable power of attorney for healthcare AND finances early as judgment may be impaired before memory
Do not drive; FTD impairs judgment, impulse control, and decision-making even if memory appears intact
Remove access to weapons, power tools, and dangerous equipment due to impaired judgment and safety awareness
Supervise financial decisions; patients with FTD are vulnerable to fraud, impulsive spending, and poor judgment
Secure medications to prevent accidental or intentional overdose; use locked medication storage
Monitor for wandering; consider GPS tracking devices and door alarms as disease progresses
Report diagnosis to DMV per state requirements; most states require physician reporting for unsafe drivers
Genetic testing results have implications for family members; discuss with genetic counselor before testing

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Structured daily routine with consistent schedule reduces anxiety and behavioral symptoms
Regular physical activity (walking, supervised exercise) improves mood and maintains function
Simplified communication using short sentences, yes/no questions, and visual cues for PPA variants
Avoid overstimulation; reduce noise, crowds, and complex environments that trigger agitation
Caregiver education through AFTD (Association for Frontotemporal Degeneration) resources and support groups
Respite care for caregivers to prevent burnout; FTD caregiving is particularly demanding due to behavioral symptoms
Address hyperorality and dietary changes with portion control, healthy snack availability, and locked food storage if needed
Safe environment modifications: remove fall hazards, lock cabinets with dangerous items, install stove knob covers
One-to-one supervision may be needed for safety; consider adult day programs or in-home care
Smoking cessation and alcohol avoidance to prevent additional brain injury and drug interactions

Patient Instructions.item: Return immediately if sudden severe headache, new weakness, or altered consciousness develops (may indicate shunt malfunction or complication)

Adequate hydration to maintain optimal CSF dynamics; avoid dehydration
Bladder training program in conjunction with physical therapy for urinary symptoms

Optic Neuritis.title: Optic Neuritis
Optic Neuritis.scope: ** Acute evaluation and management of optic neuritis in adults. Covers typical demyelinating optic neuritis, atypical features requiring expanded workup, MS risk stratification, ONTT-based treatment, and NMO/MOG antibody evaluation. For established MS with optic neuritis as a relapse, can also use "MS - Exacerbation" template.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Metabolic screen, renal function for contrast

Extended Workup.rationale: Combined NMO/MOGAD screen; critical for atypical cases

Essential/First-line.item: MRI orbits with contrast (fat-suppressed T1, STIR)
Essential/First-line.target: Optic nerve enhancement, swelling; enhancement >50% nerve length suggests atypical/NMOSD

Essential/First-line.item: MRI brain with and without contrast (MS protocol)
Essential/First-line.target: Demyelinating lesions (periventricular, juxtacortical, infratentorial); determines MS risk

Essential/First-line.item: MRI C-spine with and without contrast
Essential/First-line.target: Cord lesions supporting MS diagnosis

Extended.target: Prolonged P100 latency (confirms optic nerve dysfunction)
RNFL thickening acutely; thinning at follow-up indicates axonal loss

Referrals & Consults.item: Neuro-ophthalmology referral for comprehensive evaluation and follow-up
Neurology/MS specialist referral if brain MRI shows demyelinating lesions
Ophthalmology referral if neuro-ophthalmology unavailable or alternate diagnosis suspected
MS specialist/Neuroimmunology for DMT discussion if MS criteria met
Low vision rehabilitation if significant persistent visual impairment
Occupational therapy for ADL adaptation if functional visual impairment
Social work for disability resources if visual impairment affects employment

Patient Instructions.item: Vision typically improves over 2-4 weeks; 90%+ recover to 20/40 or better within 1 year
Return immediately if vision worsening after initial improvement (may indicate new attack or alternate diagnosis)
Return if new symptoms: weakness, numbness, imbalance, bladder problems (may indicate MS)
Do not drive if vision in affected eye prevents safe driving; check with state DMV regarding vision requirements
Heat may temporarily worsen symptoms (Uhthoff phenomenon) - this is not a new attack or permanent worsening
Expect temporary steroid side effects: insomnia, mood changes, increased appetite, metallic taste during IV infusion
Do not stop oral prednisone abruptly if on taper (adrenal suppression risk)
Monitor blood sugars if diabetic - steroids elevate glucose
Avoid sick contacts while on high-dose steroids (immunosuppression)
Keep follow-up appointments - important to monitor for MS development
Contact physician if fever, new headache, or worsening vision on steroids

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Smoking cessation - smoking increases MS conversion risk and worsens outcomes
Vitamin D supplementation 2000-5000 IU daily (target serum 25-OH vitamin D >40 ng/mL) - low levels associated with MS risk
Avoid prolonged heat exposure (hot tubs, saunas, exercising in heat) which can temporarily worsen vision (Uhthoff)
Use sunglasses if photophobia present
Regular aerobic exercise as tolerated once acute symptoms resolve
Adequate sleep (7-8 hours nightly) and stress management
Eye protection during activities if monocular vision (loss of depth perception)

differential.features: Severe vision loss (often <20/200); bilateral simultaneous or sequential; poor recovery; longitudinally extensive optic nerve enhancement (>50% nerve length)
differential.tests: AQP4-IgG positive (Mayo CDS1 or NMOFS); MRI pattern

differential.features: Often bilateral; anterior optic nerve involvement; perineural enhancement ("optic nerve sheath sign"); disc edema more prominent; better steroid response; tends to relapse
Sudden painless vision loss; altitudinal field defect; disc edema with hemorrhages; age >50; vascular risk factors (hypertension, diabetes)
differential.tests: ESR/CRP for GCA; fluorescein angiography; cardiovascular risk assessment

differential.features: Age >50; headache; jaw claudication; scalp tenderness; elevated ESR/CRP; bilateral risk
differential.tests: ESR, CRP, temporal artery biopsy; prompt treatment to prevent fellow eye

differential.features: Bilateral disc edema; transient visual obscurations; headache worse lying down; no RAPD unless asymmetric
differential.tests: LP with elevated opening pressure; MRI/MRV for venous sinus thrombosis

differential.features: Progressive vision loss; proptosis; may have disc pallor or edema; optic canal mass
differential.tests: MRI orbits showing mass lesion; CT for bony detail

differential.features: Painless; young males; sequential bilateral (weeks to months); central scotoma; no enhancement on MRI
Bilateral symmetric; ethambutol, methanol, B12/folate deficiency; cecocentral scotoma
differential.tests: B12, folate, medication history, alcohol use

differential.features: May mimic optic neuritis; other neurologic signs; risk factors
Granulomatous optic neuropathy; uveitis; other systemic involvement
Bilateral disc edema; obese young female; headache; transient visual obscurations
differential.tests: LP with elevated opening pressure; normal MRI/MRV

evidence.recommendation: IV methylprednisolone accelerates visual recovery but does not change final outcome
Oral prednisone alone (1 mg/kg) increases recurrence rate - avoid as monotherapy
Visual prognosis excellent: 90%+ recover to 20/40 or better by 1 year
Brain MRI lesions predict MS: 50% at 15 years with ≥1 lesion vs 25% with normal MRI
evidence.source: [Beck RW et al. NEJM 2003 (ONTT 10-year)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/12660385/); [Optic Neuritis Study Group 2008 (15-year)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/18332318/)

evidence.recommendation: Cell-based assay (FACS) preferred for AQP4/MOG antibody testing
evidence.source: [Pittock SJ et al. Neurology 2019](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/31434689/); [Waters P et al. J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry 2014](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/24009151/)

evidence.recommendation: MOG-IgG associated with better visual recovery and relapsing course
PLEX beneficial for steroid-refractory demyelinating optic neuritis
VEP shows prolonged P100 latency in optic neuritis
OCT RNFL thinning correlates with visual outcomes
Vitamin D deficiency associated with increased MS risk after optic neuritis
Smoking increases MS conversion risk after CIS

monitoring.action: If no improvement by 2 weeks, reconsider diagnosis or escalate treatment
Insulin sliding scale; endocrine consult if persistent >250
>20 micron loss associated with poorer outcome

monitoring.frequency: 3-6 months after initial; annually if MS risk
monitoring.action: If new lesions: MS diagnosed, start DMT

monitoring.frequency: Repeat at 3-6 months if initially negative but atypical features
monitoring.action: If seroconversion: diagnosis changes, different treatment

disposition.criteria: Mild-moderate vision loss with stable exam; able to perform ADLs safely; IV steroids completed or not indicated; reliable follow-up within 1-2 weeks with neuro-ophthalmology or neurology; understands return precautions

Severe vision loss (20/200 or worse); bilateral involvement; diagnostic uncertainty requiring expedited workup; unable to care for self safely at home due to vision loss; IV steroids indicated and outpatient infusion not available
Not typically required for isolated optic neuritis; consider if concurrent severe neurologic involvement (e.g., NMOSD with myelitis and respiratory compromise)
Neuro-ophthalmology or MS specialist not available; PLEX needed but unavailable; MRI unavailable for urgent imaging
